reviewText:
This is an interesting game. Mostly due to the fact that you play a guy who just wants some sleep (which I can relate) and he goes around murdering parties full of people to get it (I cannot relate to this).

I mean there isn’t much else to say about the game. It’s like playing a horror game in which you are the killer. You must be creative using traps in the environment to kill people. Though I still question why there was a panda at that party.

You can use Stun bombs, or smoke grenades, change of clothes (which I still find interesting that you can change in front of a cop and they immediately leave you alone)

A big part of the party will change if you fail, some traps might not be there, the item pickup will be different. So something you did that worked before, mig11ht not work again.

You can shove people off of roofs, throw them in fires, roll a car over a crowd. All that matters in this game is that you don’t get caught by the cops, or the ridiculous bouncers.

Which leads me to my first complaint.
The bouncers.

I can understand the cops, and their Speedy Mc Speed Speed to catch you.
What I don’t understand is that if you waltz near a bouncer you instantly get curb stomped for breathing his air. I mean it’s a party, and that is just mean. I just want to go hang out with sally over there, maybe get a little stabby, but nooooooooo. Mr. Bouncer here is going to chase me around first.

Also the difficulty ramps up and down like no ones business. Some levels have passages that allow you to shoot around them sneaky like, and others don’t. Learning which do and don’t make your game much more enjoyable. If on the levels with these you over-use them, some mario looking mother-f****er shows up and smacks it till it’s shut.

But really, that’s all I have an issue with.

There’s a story built into the game, is it on par with a big budget title, no. But for the price you can’t argue with it. And really for the price it’s a steal. It’s a solid game, entertaining enough while allowing me to Dexter all over the place (just don’t take it seriously). The music is great and gets stuck in your head. Just keep in mind that with this game what you see is what you get. This is a pixel game where you stab other pixels in the most creative and inconspicuous way that you can. It doesn’t get really any deeper than that.


The game never takes itself seriously, nor does it ever appear to promote any sort of actual violence. There are clowns, horses and cows dancing around.

The game seemingly has intergration with Twitch streaming, which I’ve not yet tested, but I would love to do so. (twitch.tv/8bitlanparty) /endnamedropping

At it’s core Party Hard is a romp through an 80’s inspired party scene that knows just how much it can get away with, it’s a stealth game of a new variety and it doesn’t step on anyone’s toes other than the most conservative person in the room, and even then, if they can’t laugh because a horse just kicked the player in the face and ended their murder spree, well they should probably have left the room a while ago.

The question of the hour, would I recommend this game.
Would I recommend it to a friend?

Yes, for the price I’ve already gotten more than enough entertainment to make it worth it, and I foresee much more enjoyment out of it.

Would I let my son play it? No, but he’s 9. Why are you asking if this would be okay for a kid?

reviewText:
Party Hard is a slightly randomized strategy / stealth game where you have to kill everyone in a level, without getting caught.
The game has a beautiful and richly detailed pixel art style and is accompanied by a thumping dance soundtrack, perfectly fitting the levels (which are all parties).

Randomization means that while a level will always be the same in layout, the placement of party-ers and other elements can change. One time you may see a drug deal or robbery take place, another time you load it the same room will simply be empty or filled with a beer keg instead.
The various pick-ups which can spawn, or be delivered by a helper character, will also be random. This makes each playthrough unique.

Getting caught by the police means restarting the entire level (with new randomization), so you don't just have to rehash the exact same level.

There is also optional integration with Twitch chat for streamers, where your viewers can trigger some of the random events. These range from relatively normal like extra party goers, to a zombie invasion or a Sharknado. Seriously.

Fortunately these elements can also occur at random in a singleplayer game without Twitch involvement.

The game is almost punishingly tough at times and at others laughably easy, even on the same level, thanks to the randomization, but that's part of its charm.

Beating the game unlocks extra characters who have their own characteristics, for the completionists.

There's also a story tying the levels together, but that's just your cliché slasher film affair. It doesn't add much but doesn't distract either -- at least it's told in beautiful pixel art comic style.

Worth picking up if it meets your price point. As I'm writing this review I'm 5 hours in, not beating the game yet, and I pid about 6.50 for my copy. At a Euro per hour, it's a good deal for me, since I enjoyed every second of it.
Even replaying the same level six times in a row because I got impatient and got caught...

reviewText:
I enjoyed Party Hard so much I'm actually writing a review for it, something I've never done for any other game.  It has a fantastic concept, great game mechanics, and a very surprising and IMO captivating story.  It's challenging, but in a way that isn't overly frustrating; it requires patience, persistence, a lot of running, and planning, and it's oh so satisfying to get to stab somebody.

It's also pretty funny how hell-bent on partying these people are that they'll witness all these people get murdered and STILL stick around.

If you enjoy good old fashioned murder this is an excellent game for it!!

reviewText:
This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer.
Party Hard is a stealth action based title released in August of 2015 developed by Pinokl Games and published by tinyBuild. You play the character of someone who just hates the loud noises of late night partying and you go on a murdering spree across America to put a stop to it.

The game is played in an almost isometric view as you control your character. You have the choice of a few different characters to play as on some levels, the most fun I found has to be the ninja character - who doesn't love a massive ninja blade?! Each of the characters have their own special equipment, as well as being able to pick up extra equipment that is scattered around all of the levels. The aim of the game is to kill everyone at the party without being caught by the authorities, whether it is the police or security guards. The way you kill people can be as creative as you like, some of the best ways I found would be causing dance floors to explode, pushing people off boats into shark pools and nudging people into air vents to get blended into a fine puree! If any of the other part goers see you kill someone, you either have to be very quick to escape the scene before they can call the cops, or well....take them out too. Either way you have to be very quick with your actions and this can lead to some very hectic chain killing scenarios as well. The game expects this to happen as it also rewards you for pulling off long chains of combo kills.  After you kill someone, you of course need to deal with their body; so again think creative, dumping bodies in dumpsters, haystacks, sewer pipes, all become common ways of  getting rid of the evidence but there are plenty of ways to hide them if you put your mind to it.

A lot of time you have to pick your moments when to strike very wisely, being patient certainly pays off here rather than going in gung-ho all of the time. If you stalk your prey and wait for them to separate from the crowd, you are going to get away with murders a lot easier than doing it in the middle of a crowded dance floor. Although, that being said, you are also rewarded with a higher score at the end of each level for completing it in as fast of a time as you can - catch 22! I personally went with the slow and steady approach.

Party Hard has a very pleasing graphical art style, the pixel graphics are represented very well here, and has a very much same look to it as some games such as Hotline Miami. Even though there aren’t massive amounts of detail in any of the character models, you still feel as if they are fleshed out and all feel alive and vibrant.

The plot in Party Hard is very much a detective style story, and although it has serious undertones, it isn't a massively complex story that should be taken very seriously at all. The story itself is mainly progressed through the cut scenes in between each level, and the voice acting is at times OK at best, one of the characters voices is really whiny and actually starts to grow very thin on your annoyance levels at times. Party Hard's soundtrack is awesome though - obviously since all of the gameplay takes place at a party, you are going to have party tracks, so upbeat high temp songs on every level keep the gameplay feeling even more fast pace than it should be.

This is a pretty difficult game - it takes a good session for you to be able to get to grips with how to actually kill off almost fifty or so people every level without being caught, and it does take a decent amount of skill and practice to be able to pull it off, with maybe a pinch of luck too. Be expected to fail a few times on each level as you work out the best ways to knock people off in the most effective way possible.

Each of the levels in Party Hard has an element that is procedurally generated, but the main gist of the map will remain the same throughout. All of the maps have a variety of different interact-able objects that you can use in your murderess plans and it is highly encouraged that you do so as otherwise it will be really difficult to progress. A couple of the levels have shortcuts allowing you to easily traverse from one side of the map to the other, making quick get-aways even easier to pull off - don't use them too much though since they do actually get blocked off after a few uses to stop you taking advantage of them.

I have been playing Party Hard offline on a laptop for a few days now, and it has taken me almost four hours to complete the game's substantial amount of levels. I was perfectly happy with that time, and given that there is also an element of replay ability in that levels are randomly generated, and unlock-able extra characters, then you really get your money’s worth out of this game. There are about 6 or so extra characters to unlock - so you can squeeze about 15 hours or so of gameplay out of this title if you so desired.

Party Hard is a technically sound game, I didn't have any issues at all whilst playing. The game is strongly recommended that you use a gamepad, simply because just works and feels better on a pad than keyboard. At the time of writing this review, I couldn't get used to using the Steam Controller with it though, so would recommend you stick with an Xbox pad for now.

To sum up, Party Hard is an excellent little title that I wasn't really expecting much from, but was pleasantly surprised. The game has a brilliant art style and amazing sound track. This is a game play element which I have not seen before so it was nice to see something original and done to a high standard. If you can ignore the voice acting sloppy voice acting in the cut scenes, then I wouldn't say there is that much wrong with this game. The regular price tag of £9,99 is priced for the amount of replay ability in this game too. Stealth genre fans will get a massive kick out of the game, and anyone wanting to play a game that is a little different to the Hotline Miami franchise, will certainly find a huge amount of enjoyment in Party Hard.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
The soundtrack is amazing, I would probably buy it on it's own.

The story is decent, about as good as it can be for a game where your only real objective is to murder all the annoying people at a party.

I used a horse to murder someone...

I was annoyed by everyone else on the dance floor, and decided to venture into the bathroom only to stumble on two young party goers trying to have sex. Sorry... the only thing that's getting penetrated in this bathroom is both of your faces! *stab* *stab* (with a knife, not my man parts)

After that was all done, I ventured into the kitchen, only to find a cowboy there wearing what looked like ♥♥♥-less chaps. What kind of party is this?! So I poisoned the chili. Enjoy the f*ckin food partner!

Then I walked outside onto the balcony only to find a woman out there having a smoke. Sorry, I'll just kill you now, and save you the trouble! *stab*

Then I found another guy outside, passed out - covered in vomit. You know, the type of guy to go into your bathroom drunk and take a poop on your toilet seat lid? Yeah... no one will miss you *stab*.

I also then used a nearby tree to kill a cop.

This game plays like a dream, if in your dreams you see yourself murdering every single one of your annoying neighbors.

10/10 would stab again.

reviewText:
Nap all day, sleep all night, party never :D

+ Pixel art graphics.
+ Psychedelic lights and colors.
+ Cool soundtrack.
+ Nice audio effects. Loved the bathroom's thrilling sounds.
+ Easy gameplay.
+ Awesome characters and unique abilities.
+ All kinds of people and creatures! Security guards, soldiers, zombies, aliens etc.
+ Each map is almost different with generated traps and can be played with different approaches.
+ Campaign story was ok.

- I would love to see more details at better resolutions
- It would be nice to be able to kill cops, engineers and medics (Cops, SWAT and FBI agents can be killed by traps though).
- Music tracks are few and feel repetitive after some time. But, putting the music volume to zero and playing some random electronic from your library, fits with the atmosphere as well.
- Medics ignore you when you kill people in front of them.
- The DJ keeps playing after you decapitate him (lol).
- Some obstacles may block you badly.

I had a lot of fun playing this game as it may provide awesome, but also frustrating moments.
Each playable character is challenging and most of the time it requires patience, speed and some luck.
There are moments, when you may lose at the beginning of a stage or at the end, having one or two victims remaining.
But it was awesome at some points when I decided to go berserk and try to catch up and kill all before calling the cops.

I hope there will be a sequel and a map editor.

Added to favorites.

reviewText:
Party Hard is a game that proudly wears its 80s slasher influence on its (blood-stained) sleeve.

Combining the aesthetic from Hotline Miami, every John Carpenter horror film you've ever seen and the quirkiness that comes standard in games published by TinyBuild Games, Party Hard is a incredibly enjoyable retro stealth title that offers hours of replayability and fun, though with a handful of elements that could be improved.

You play as a man who is brought in for questioning by a police officer, and tells his story of being present at certain murder scenes. These cutscenes act as a framing device for the levels themselves, which task you with killing everyone however you see fit due to your hatred of loud music. Poisoned drinks, environmental hazards, errant golf carts, malfunctioning power boxes, subterfuge... it's all here, just begging to be exploited and used on the unsuspecting yuppies and partygoers that populate the parties.

You'd never know that this was developer Pinoki Games' first stealth action title, because the controls and level setups are honed incredibly well. The player character is just an everyday guy (with a knife), and has several disadvantages that players have to utilize and exploit to overcome large crowds. You can't run as fast as the police, so you always have to be thinking two steps ahead when you decide to stab someone. You can sabotage items and lead NPCs to beat up each other in confusion. You can set up explosive/environmental traps and use the scattering crowd to mask your exploits. You can even set up long chains of kills and go for high-score combo bonuses. Digital murder never felt so fun.

Party Hard is very well-crafted in that respect, and encourages replayability to understand. It's a joy to run through levels and try for high scores, helped by the fact that each level is semi-randomized and doesn't always have the same traps as the last time you played it.

That being said, the game can also be punishing at times. You'll almost certainly experience situations where you get beaten up (for dancing, ironically), and have to wait for a minute while your character lies sleeping on the ground. Dealing with the cops requires the player to have an almost-clairvoyant sense of the level design and where a cop is going to run at you from, and it's all too easy to be close to a dead body when someone walks near and blames you.

It also feels like a game that was made, first and foremost, for Twitch streaming. The story is disposable filler, and the real joy comes from the randomized events that are proudly showcased by the developers (allowing the streamer to be influenced by rare events that are voted on by viewers). However, at present, these events aren't accessible at all in the single-player mode.

The game also has two additional characters that unlock after the ending, but I didn't really see the advantage in using them. It's far more fun just to use the default character and work around his weaknesses.

In the end, Party Game is one of my favorite titles so far this year. I've put in 25 hours myself, and there's something strangely compelling that keeps me coming back for more.

Unn tiss unn tiss, baby.

reviewText:
Party Hard:
~~~~~~~~~

Inspector John West has seen and hunted down plenty of criminals during his time but nothing could prepare him for the streak of killings like this! A party killer who has marked him forever!

Party Hard is an action/stealth/ strategy game were you are playing an insomniac psychopath (at the start of the game and you will be able to play others during the course of the game) who has had enough of loud parties. Armed with a knife, you will join and disrupt 19 parties across the great U.S. of A! In each party, you will be able to use some objects and make deadly traps out of them and hopefully wipe out a large number of partygoers. Look around for suitcases, they have items that could be very useful for your killing spree: smoke grenades, which are great to conceal yourself while ravaging the party; stun grenades, which are helpful for a short time; dynamite, which needs to be placed in the right spot to be effective, but will trigger the SWAT team to come around.

If you can’t find any suitcases, look out for the guy with a black coat and hat - he always has great goodies (another insomniac, I guess)! Make sure nobody sees you doing your grim business or the police will be on your tail and escaping is not that easy! Random events can help you too, you might be lucky and a bear can jump into the middle of a party and ransack it for you! A bit like a Spanish toreador, just watch and enjoy!

I really like the randomization in this game, each time you restart a party objects might not be in the same place as your last attempt, and they might not be there at all. Which gives this game a good re-playability. It is a challenging game and it will take you several efforts to ruin a party to death!

Nice pixel graphics with a funky audio! I really enjoy the pixel art through the story too. You can either use the keyboard or a gamepad for the control. I personally prefer the gamepad. I reckon it is easier.

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Partially randomize levels
-	Nice pixel graphics and great audio
-	Fun and easy to play
-	Trading cards and achievements

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Challenging at times

Partying too hard can be deadly indeed but this time you will be the executor!

9/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

reviewText:
Party Hard is an amazing stealth action game that looks great, plays great and sounds great. After quite a few hours played, this is now one of my favourite games.
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

What is happening in the game:Your neighbours are having a party just when you wanted to get some sleep. In order to stop them, you have to, well, kill them. All of them.

Pros:    Graphics | This game truly looks awesome. Just look at the screenshots! Everything is coloured just right, the shadows and lights look good, the animations are also great ... I seriously love it. Pixel-ish graphics are usually not my cup of tea, but this one is certainly a masterpiece.
Soundtrack | Another great thing about this game. Since there is no soundtrack DLC (licensing issues, sadly), I sometimes just leave the game running to listen to music. I don't know who is the author, but he is really talented.
Storyline | A piece of a story comes with each level. You are being interrogated about the mysterious serial killer. The story is really interesting and I like how it develops together with your progress in the game.
Characters | There are a few different characters. To unlock them, you need to beat certain levels or unlock achievements. The idea of the gameplay stays basically the same, however, your abilities to kill are changed and it brings in many additional hours of gameplay.
Level Layouts | Every level is slightly different. There are different traps, escape paths, rooms, hiding spots, guard placements and many other things. I really like how some achievements are more appropriate for some maps, while other maps are just extremely fun to repeat many times without any obligations.
Level Editor + Workshop | Recently, Workshop support was added to Party Hard. You can now build your own levels and share them with others. The editor is powerful and you can build your levels almost exactly how you want them to be. You can browse community levels in a very convenient level browser from inside the game.
Controller Support | I don't write this often, but I have to say that I had a lot of fun playing this game with a controller and it plays with it better than most games.
Twitch Integration | If you're a streamer and want to engage your audience, this game makes this really easy. Your viewers can select random events that occur every once in a while and make your gameplay more random and sometimes a bit more challenging. This is definitely a very good way to promote your game as well. I was just a part of a live stream recently and it was very fun influencing the game someone else was playing.
Steam Integration | There are Trading Cards and Achievements enabled for this game. Achievements are very fun in this game, although some of them need a lot of work and, if you're into that, using scripts for launching the game very many times.
Supported Operating Systems | This game runs on Windows, SteamOS and MacOS. I had the chance to try it on two of those systems and both builds were running flawlessly.
Cons:    FBI Agents | When you kill too many police officers, FBI Agents come to the party and start searching the area. The problem is that, somehow, they know very well where to look for which sometimes doesn't really feel very fair. But you shouldn't really make them come to the party very often, which doesn't make this a very big problem.
Limited-use Escape Paths | Well, I don't mind that you can't use escape infinitely many times, but I would really like to have a few more uses instead of just one or two.
No Steam Cloud Support | Sadly, you lose your progress if you switch to a different computer. It should be a relatively easy thing to do, so I don't know why it's not implemented yet.
The final verdict:This is easily one of the most fun games I've played in a long long time. The music makes an awesome party ambience and the gameplay makes an awesome, uhhmm, killing ambience? Anyway, this game looks damn pretty, it has many many hours of gameplay and an awesome story.
If you have the money, buy it. It's definitely worth it.

Greetings,
BirdCute

Note that my copy of this game was obtained for free for reviewing purposes. However, this did not affect the quality and objectivity of this review.
---
No drama, Just Reviews.

reviewText:
**Key was donated from the developer to review**

Introduction            Party Hard is in the same family of the highly acclaimed Hotline Miami. The main difference between these two games is the fact that Party Hard is a slower paced stealth game, but besides that they so incredibly similar. Party Hard has an amazing art style and soundtrack. Just like Hotline Miami it also has an incredible funny story. To sum it all up Party Hard is about ta serial killer who kills people who are being loud at parties because he just wants some quiet. The only thing that I could honestly dislike about the game is the voice acting sounds like it’s all done by the same person. Besides that Party Hard is a incredibly fun game that everyone should try.

-HiPFiRED

Pros
Fun Story
Great Art Style
Awesome Soundtrack
Slowed Down Stealth Hotline Miami Gameplay is Tons of Fun

Cons

reviewText:
I'll start my review with this statement: It's good and has a lot of potential but it does not feel finished.

I originally bought this game as it looked a lot like Hotline Miami and its premise seemed similar. Instead of Hotline Miami, the game feels like a top down Hitman game, albeit the difference being that you must kill everyone while avoiding detection. It's very fun but is marred by a few issues, these being:

*Glitch that can happen where random NPCs can act as bouncers (bouncers are a 1 hit kill NPC)
*The movement speed... oh god, the movement speed. You walk at the speed of molasses on a cold winter day. The run speed is tolerable but does not last nearly long enough and takes forever to regenerate. NPCs, even when not panicked, can sometimes walk faster than you and you can't really do anything except either burn your run meter or wait til they stop. It's just painfully slow how slow you move.
*The lack of characters. They're all essentially pallet swaps (2 literally being pallet swaps with no abilities) and it just ends up being very limited with not much replay value.
*The voice acting is House of the Dead 2 levels of awful. I get that it's an indie game but there's a good reason why games like Hotline Miami didn't have voice overs.
*Highly exploitable AI. The game becomes ridiculously easy when you realize that only one person can call the cops, so you can go on a mass murder spree and as long as you stop and get away from any bodies when the cop arrives, everyone forgets you did anything. It makes the core gameplay trivial button mashing instead of being methodical.
*No replay factor at all. No real unlocks as all the characters follow the same general ruleset and there's no hard mode, level editor or anything like that.

But I do recommend this game; really, I do. It's fairly unique at what it does, has an excellent soundtrack and good use of pixel art. Playing it sly like it's intended is always fun as you try to outwit the massive ammount of NPCs clustered together. With a few bit of changes and more content, it could be as good as Hotline Miami though instead of a high octane feel, it's a more smooth, methodical game. If you can get it cheap, by all means go for it. If not, it's still a very solid game for its price.

reviewText:
Simply fun! Party Hard puts you in the shoes of effectively a 90's Slasher movie, where you are the serial killer.

You travel the country going party to party, silencing the fun, and ending all heavy parties you can. In between each level is a rather interesting little narration/interview where a police detective is being interviewed about the case and what they tried to do to catch you.

It makes the rather long loading screens bearable , as this takes place during each level.
The soundtrack is also great, although I would have liked if more tracks were played during each level. For me it takes an average of 30 minutes per Party; and during that time difference music would be fantastic.
As mentioned the average level takes me around 30 minutes, this is because you have to be rather patient during your kills.

You can't just go nuts and slash madly, you have take your time; wait for someone to be isolated and then deal with them. Accidents are key though, and the more the better. Sabotage items, and have people fall for that. That way you don't have the attention drawn to you.

Even with as many precautions as possible though, make sure you are Never spotted near a body. Even if it was an accident, if no one saw the accident, and they then see you they will instantly connect you to the death and call the police.

If the police is called on you though, you can escape them. First you can try and find a change of clothes, that'll make them lose you right away. The other method is to use trap doors to move between areas. Eventually the police officer will get tired and just leave.

Once this happens though; Mario shows up and proceeds the lock and block off these escape routes.

Occasionally you also need to deal with Bouncers; which will beat you down until you die. Avoid them, until you get the chance to take them down which can be a challenge.


All in all Party Hard is a heck of a lot of fun. I've played 6 levels so far and I'm still really enjoying it.
I would happily recommend it to anyone.

PC Gameplay Footage
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p5aR3Fmb4ZA

reviewText:
IntroductionI hate parties. There, I said it. They make me feel awkward and there always seems to be a forced atmosphere. It’s not that I want to murder everyone when I’m being at a party, though, so when Party Hard came along I was intrigued by the idea to say the least. So, if you’re like me, and want to know if you’ll have a better time playing this game than being at an actual party read on!

GameplayClearly the game is meant to be over-the-top, while still feeling somewhat realistic in terms of environments and kills. Yes, ‘somewhat’, because even though your goal is to kill everyone at the party you can’t go around and stab everyone just in the face and be done with it (well, you can try, but you’ll most likely end up being arrested or beaten up).

The story is being told through flashbacks of the events that (recently) occurred – these are your missions - while cutscenes tell us a bit more about the current situation. This is mostly told through a detective’s perspective (who is being questioned/asked about the killings), but to avoid possible spoilers I won’t go into it any further than this.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=527066665
The game’s style reminded me a bit of Hotline Miami. It’s not as vibrant, though, and a lot of the people found in the levels won’t even fight back. This doesn’t make it easy, mind you. On the contrary: although it’s not a main objective the goal is to still try and create a big combo in order to score big points. You will have to rely on luck, stealth and skill in order to do this. I’ve managed to create a combo of, I think, 10-12 or so, but that was because a lot of the people were turned into zombies and standing close to one another, since, well, zombies are mindless. Again, it sounds very easy this way, but trust me when I say that I had to retry the level more than once.

The levels are pretty big in size, but they’re limited to just one screen. Despite that there is still more than enough detail in them and you also have plenty of room to move around (freely). Unfortunately, it can be hard to see where you can or can’t walk sometimes because everything is shown in 2D with pixelated graphics and because of that objects sometimes lack the fine(r) detail that normally distinguishes these parts (a bit) better.
Levels include a cruise ship, dance club, biker party and garden party (and many others!) and the AI characters move around freely in all of these levels, doing their own things. This can frequently become annoying, though, because your character doesn’t stand out all that much and if there are a couple of people (walking) near you you might just lose track of it all.

So the goal is to kill all of the people who are currently present at the party. The people are randomly generated so if you play the same level a different time then you will have to kill a different amount of people. Same goes for the available objects in the level. Some of them are static, but some of these are also randomly generated and placed. It adds a bit of replay value but to be honest there’s not much incentive to replay a level once it’s finished, unless you want to improve your high score.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=527066628
You will be able to kill people by stabbing them or by using the environments to make it seem like an accident. Keep in mind, however, that you must not be caught, because if you’re close to a murder scene then it’s likely you will be pointed out as the murderer. The police will then chase you until you’re caught or until they’re too tired to chase you further. You can then start killing again, just like before. If you’re lucky a different guest will be arrested and this will then also count as a ‘kill’. So sometimes it pays off (but most of the times it doesn’t, because crime doesn’t pay!).

From time to time you will also be able to find items in the levels in the form of a suitcase and once opened these will give you either a smoke bomb, explosive bomb or different clothes (handy if you’re being chased), among a couple of other items.

You can also use a dance move to spread out groups of people (because they somehow don’t like the way you dance; well, it’s their loss) and you also have a sprint button (with limited, but rechargeable stamina bar) and a listen button that shows you all of the available interactive objects around you.

Audio & VisualsThe music is just amazing; there are a lot of catchy, upbeat songs, and best of all, this music would actually fit in a game about parties. Just for the music alone I could easily recommend this game. The sounds effects are mostly basic but, as always, at least get the job done. The voice acting ranges from mediocre to good, but I *think* this might have been done on purpose, since it’s meant as an over-the-top experience.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=527066688
Visually the game also looks stunning; it uses beautiful retro graphics and a realistic color pattern/scheme. Only problem is, unfortunately, that the graphics don’t have enough detail and because of that it sometimes is hard to see where you can exactly go to. I think ‘cutout’ 2D or just regular 2D graphics would’ve helped the game in this department. It’s not a big deal, but could’ve been easily avoided with a little more care (maybe even by just changing up some of the graphics).

Length/Replay ValueEach level should take you about 5-10 minutes, but it’s unlikely you’ll finish most of the levels on your first try. Since there are 12 levels I estimate it will take an average user about 5-7 hours to complete, including retries, which is more than enough in my opinion. And also considering the price, of course. We don’t want the game to overstay its welcome and thankfully it doesn’t, but this will of course differ per person in the end.

ConclusionIf you ever played Hotline Miami and wanted something similar then Party Hard might just be the thing you’re looking for. It uses similar, pretty, retro graphics, it has amazing audio and the gameplay is just solid. The story might be a bit ridiculous, but if you can look past that then there’s a fun and engaging game to be found here.

Too long, didn’t readPros:
+ Retro graphics
+ Amazing music
+ Fun, sometimes challenging, gameplay
+ Pulling off a perfect ‘run’ feels very satisfying

Mixed:
+/- Not vital, but it’s sometimes unclear where you’re character starts off
+/- Random objects and amounts of people give the game a bit of replay value, although not much
+/- Environmental kills are fun, but sometimes it’s a bit too limited (read: there aren’t always enough objects in a level to keep it (very) interesting)

Cons:
- At times there are too many people walking around, close to each other, and you can lose track of it all
- Some of the levels feel a bit empty in terms of environmental interactivity, which is disappointing

Please note: a Steam key for this game was provided by the developer.
Rating: 8.0 (out of 10)

Want to read more of my unbiased reviews? Just click here.If you have any kind of feedback - positive or negative - please feel free to leave a comment (in case of negative feedback please try to keep it constructive). It would be greatly appreciated!

reviewText:
This key was obtained from the developer

Gameplay Footage and Video Review: https://youtu.be/YLIH2nQRdak

Summary:
Party Hard plays as a stealth game with action elements, as you attempt to murder everything in sight without getting caught. The core of the game comes down to strategy in where to take out victims and where to be patient: and that part of the game does truly work. If you're expecting an action game with tons of killing sprees in short bursts: you are probably looking in the wrong place (although it CAN happen). The levels in their first few playthroughs work, but eventually they will only really be replayable for those who like score attacks and perfecting runs. It gets the subtle humor of a horror movie down with little things, and overall, it's the kind of game that some gameplay footage shows exactly what kind of game it is: and that's a good thing. Whether or not it's for you is whether you like the strategy stealth genre, and if you have patience.

Lists:

+:
Strategy gameplay at the core is fun if you play it like a stealth game, which is actually is in my opinion. Waiting to take out a person and hiding the body has it's own thrill to it.
The goofy sense of humor, not just in the story, but in the little things that the game has inside of it, put a smile on my face. Feels like a horror movie at the core.
Enemy AI does enough to cause you problems without being overly complicated. You want “lambs” to the slaughter here, and it does enough to keep a challenge without taking that away.
Music and environments work.
The dance button. It serves a purpose, but it's so goofy fun to use.
-:
Over time, variety in stages will hurt the game as while there's some random generation of it, it's only a few items in the big picture.
Action players will probably not find the game they'd be looking for here.
Some levels can punish a mistake harshly, almost too harshly at times.
Would like to see more interactables.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: Key was provided by the publisher.

Party Hard is a game where our character, finding himself unable to sleep due to loud parties, comes to the only logical conclusion: Kill everyone at the party, and then do the same to parties all over the US.


For this, you have several tools at your disposal. Throughout the level there will be several traps you can use. Many of them are randomly spawned in set locations, so you might have different opportunities and ways of approaching the level each time you play.Placement of the victims in the level is also randomly set to an extent, as are some events (sometimes a robbery can take place, a drug deal, etc, etc) You will be able to poison food and drinks, tinker with electric devics, rig speakers to explode, start the engine of cars so it runs over, people, etc. You will also find tools like stun bombs, bombs, new clothes and smoke bombs on a briefcase that it's somewhere on the level, or given to you by a strange man in a trenchcoat.

The game in concept feels somewhat like a mix of Hotline Miami and Hitman, coupled with a soundtrack that wouldn't be out of place in the former. While good, the soundtrack really needs some more inclusions, since you will restart the levels several times and many of the tracks are shared between levels, so it can eventually become somewhat annoying and make you mute the music.

You are encouraged to keep it stealthy, as otherwise the witnesses will call the police and pin you as the murderer, which will run after you and most likely catch you, as sadly in this game your own movement is too slow, and the sprint ability is both way too short and takes too long to refill"

reviewText:
||||||||||||||Please read the full review to find out why I don't recommend it. The points I make may not bother you and you may still enjoy the game.|||||||||||||||||||

Title: Party Hard
Genre: Action, Indie, Strategy
Developer: Pinokl Games
Publisher: tinyBuild
Release Date: 25 Aug, 2015

Game key was supplied by the publisher.

--------------------------------------

Party Hard is a top down, 2D,  mass murder simulator in which you play as a someone who gets a little cheesed off at his neighbours for having an extremely loud party at 3am. He decides to take matters into his own hands and goes on a murderous rampage. As you do.

As much as I hate to say it, that is pretty much it with the story. However, you do get a quick cutscene between each mission which shows the story of detective John West as he tries to catch the ‘Party Hard Killer’. Although these cutscenes are extremely badly voice acted, and even though the speaking characters are changing, it sounds like the same voice actor desperately trying to put on a different voice but failing miserably. If you are looking for a game with a detailed progressive story, this is not the game for you. Although most people buying this will see from the get-go that this game is not designed for it’s story.

The gameplay is as you would expect, fun but shallow and without any real challenge. Your character will walk around the party wielding a knife, slowly bumping each person off until no more remain.  If you murder someone, the police will pay a visit and put the body in a boby bag, leave it on the middle of the dancefloor and then bugger off somewhere else without even investigating what happened. This will continue happening as you stab as many people as you see fit until the dance floor is strewn with body bags and the rest of the party attendants still dancing their night away like nothing has even happened- occasionally going off to the buffet table because the sign off a mass murder has given them a craving for pineapple and cheese sticks.

The fun element will come from the traps that you can use throughout the map. There are a great amount of traps and each time you replay the mission, the traps may have changed or may be in a different location. These traps range from exploding speakers, to poisoning the food and even driving a car over a hoard of people (you do not control the car) However, these traps still fall under the same problem as the stabbings – the car could have driven over 10 people at once and they are now currently mush on the pavement- but nobody else will care (they won’t even call the emergency services) because THE PARTY MUST GO ON!  Trying to get the perfect ‘massacre’ is where the fun begins and ends, trying to get best kills without getting caught is really the only thing this game has to offer, which is a real shame.

If you do managed to be silly enough to get spotted and you cannot wipe them out before they get to the phone to call the police, then the police will come. Only one officer though. You now must escape. How do you do that you ask? Drive away? Kill the police office? Don’t be silly, just play the ol’ switcheroo by climbing in and out of a window (or other trap door locations) Just as the police officer gets near you, climb out of a window, and then as they try going back round the front door to get to the other side, climb back in. Once you have used an escape route to escape from a dimwitted officer, Mario will come and board it up and you cannot use it anymore (seriously, he looks like Mario).  Be careful though, the police are not the only ones who will arrive- other units such as the SWAT team and FBI can also make an appearance, which makes the game a tad bit harder.

You are able to hide bodies in certain locations. This will help stop anybody from seeing the dead partygoers and in turn, the police will not be called. The thing that irks me is that you can stuff as many bodies as you want into a dumpster. Want to cram 50 people in there? Sure, go ahead! Games such as Hitman have done this better by only allowing a maximum amount of bodies to be hidden in one location. The game would have provided gamers with a bit of a rush to make the body disposal areas in places that maybe get a bit more lively. Having a dumpster outside that only about 1 person walks to at a time makes no challenge. However, putting a disposal area in say a bedroom cupboard, where you have to quickly dispose of it before any moment someone can come walking in. (although this would not work because you can see the entire map and where everyone is at anytime, maybe they needed to add in a line of sight feature)

One of the redeeming features were the songs they used in the game, I am a bit disappointed that there was such a small amount of music variety used. What is currently there is amazing, it gets stuck in your head instantly and is very enjoyable to listen to- but a larger library of music would have been preferred.

Another redeeming feature is the graphics. This art style has been done many times in the past, so don’t expect anything to ‘wow’ you, but it really does work for this game. Everything looks simplistic and you can easily see the entire map. Saying that, there are some problems with height of things, sometimes I get caught because I think a window is a lot lower than I thought- so I couldn’t just walk under it holding a dead body over my shoulder.

All in all, I just couldn’t recommend the game, it just doesn’t do enough right for me to really enjoy playing it. If the AI reactions to murders was maybe a bit more realistic then I would have enjoyed this a lot more. There just isn’t much difficulty in a game where you can leave dead bodies around and nobody will care, the police won’t even investigate the brutal murder(s) that just happened. It seems that most missions can be done by standing by an area where bodies can be hidden and slowly killing 1 by 1 until you get to a lower number, then going and killing off anybody that’s sleeping and then activating any traps to kill more.

If you don’t mind a game that has no challenge- you just want to run around killing people in different ways and try to beat your previous times/scores- then you should take a look at buying this (you can always refund it if it’s not for you) Personally, it wasn’t for me.

reviewText:
Simple game that is deceptively complex.  Don't go in expecting Hitman.  Do go in expecting an amazing soundtrack (that loops after about 10 seconds per track) with ridiculous frivolty regarding human life.

Crowd gathered around a BBQ... I push a guy in and he burns to death.  The whole crowd runs away, but somehow no one blames me for it.  Repeat.

Crowded dance floor.  I short the fuse box which causes the floor lighting to kill all 30+ people dancing on it as they burst in to flame.  Oddly enough no one else at the party even blinks at this.  In fact, people continue to stream on to the dance floor as the people right in front of them in the conga line burst into flames.

The police give up ridiculously easily, people forget who you are if you change clothes in front of them, the art is extremely simplistic, the police murder more people than I do running them over with their car on some levels, the Engrish can be horribad (take a look at the achievement descriptions).  But, the voice acting is surprisingly good, the play controls are perfect for what they need to be, and the game levels are just short enough to not be frustrating if you lose with only a handful of people left to murder.

My one complaint is how long it can take for the game to restart a level if the police have to carry you a long way back to the car.  That and the bouncers being ridiculous to take out without a bomb or sword.

A pleasent surprise that came out of nowhere.

10/10 would lead a conga line to a firey death again.

reviewText:
Note: This game was reviewed with a code provided by the publisher.

Party Hard is a strategy, stealth game and the main goal is to kill party goers, but will you want to try it out ?

Party Hard has a really simple story. You play as a man who get's annoyed by his partying neighbors at 3 AM so you get up and wipe out the entire house. But now the quench for blood begins and you set out to kill all party goers across the US.

Gameplay is simple but it get's complicated really fast. You can do three things. You can set up traps that will killd anyone around them, you can use the knife to stab people and you can pick people up and carry them around and hide the bodies or you can pick up sleeping people and carry them and stab them. But if you slip up, the victims can call the police which will patrol around the map trying to find the killer. You can evade police but it's harder each time they arrive at the crime scene.

Graphics are simple pixel art and they look awesome. Every little detail is just awesome. From the sharknado in the Miami level to the Mad Max vehicles in the Party Bus level. All of it is just amazing.

Soundtrack is just awesome. It's awesome and I would buy it by itself, it's great. Now there's not much sound effects apart from people screaming and explosions.

The game get's incredibly difficult. The Miami level is one of the hardest things I had to do period. Overall expect a challenge when playing this game, cause it's not easy.

Level Design is pretty simple. You see the map from a over head view and you see everything from there on out. But some levels are in open areas where there's no where to hide making it a pain to play through.

The game took me 4 hours to finish every level and the Miami level took me an hour all by itself. The game has a randomized levels. But this boils down to small details like certain traps not being there and more victims in the level. You do get one more character which you can use to play through the other levels.

If this review was written five hours earlier, I would have said it's pretty buggy, but after I closed down the game I found the patch that fixed a lot of problems. The game ran smoothly from start to finish apart from a minor bug where AI would glitch into walls.

Party Hard is a really fun game and without a doubt I highly suggest to try it out. It's addictive gameplay will make you want more murder and chaos and the incredibly fun gameplay will make you come back. I give Party Hard a 8.5/10

The After Party Update: Brief Review.

The developers added 7 new parties so you can continue the rampage once more. There's nothing major to report. There parties are all the same with different objectives, like staying alive for a certain amount of time or even trying to complete a level in a certain amount of time.  These new parties are just as hard as the the main ones. It took me 3 hours in total to finish all 7 of them. I highly suggest getting the game already if you haven't.

For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
Party Hard has an interesting premise where you play the role of a psycho who simply does not like loud parties. His solution? Kill every one at the party of course! If I was to try an nail Party Hard to a single genre, I would say it's a tactical stealth game, though murder-sim also comes to mind.

The idea of putting the stealth genre into a crowded, open room, as Party Hard has done, is a pretty unique experience. In most other stealth games, the area is sparsely populated with tons of corners and objects to hide around, but in Party Hard you're in a large open room, where every one can see every one else. It makes stealth tactics much more interesting as the player will have to be creative on how he or she approach any given situation., with witnesses littered every where.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RSnDMC4SjQI
In Party Hard, the most basic way of accomplishing your goal of murder is simply to stab someone. It's also recommended that you dump the body somewhere unseen as they'll alert other party goers. The key here is not to get caught, even if someone alert the cops, as long as you don't get pined with the crime, you're still good to go. The game also gives you an assortment of randomly generated environmental traps and dangers, with each stage featuring it's own unique RNG generation. You can activate any of these traps at any given moment in order to help you murder the party. The game also encourages creative play, as each scenario plays out more like a sandbox. For example, there is a stage with a swimming pool. I got creative, and experimented with carrying passed out partiers into the pool to see if they'd drown. Indeed they did, and this is just one example of how you can get creative with the many kill tactics" available to you. The overall premise of this idea
date: with how sandboxy the stages are designed
recommended: coupled with the random event generation that comes with every play though
hoursPlayed: the game does a good job at encouraging replay
voteText: while keeping things interesting and surprising.\n\nThough the core of Party Hard is pretty enjoyable
helpfulPercent: and if nothing else
votesTotal: it's not without it's faults. Your character's movement speed is at a snail's pace
commentsCount: and slow regenerating stamina bar to help with it. It also encourages a lot of moving back and forth repetitively in order to dump bodies safely. Couple these 2 slow elements with the fact that when you fail a stage
column16: you have to start at the beginning. Considering that some of the stages can take upwards to
column17: if not over
column18: 20 minutes to complete
column19: the game can feel tedious at times.\n\nParty Hard's overall creative stealth play
column20: with it's interesting random event generation
column21: I found it more enjoyable than tedious. It's overall a very unique and enjoyable experience
column22:
though some of the tedium will turn some players off.

Pros:
- Unique stealth gameplay design
- Good visuals and audio
- Lots of dark comedy
- Random event generation keeps the game fresh

Cons:
- Punishing fail state that waste time rather than teach a lesson
- Slow movement pace
- Can be repetitive"

reviewText:
Party Hard is a well intentioned murder spree without a ton of options. You're usually walking around a party with a few traps and no way to lure people into them. After you've used all the large area traps, you'll have to bumble around hoping to widdle out the 30 or 40 people left shaking their groove thing. It's a game with an interesting idea that doesn't know how to keep the murder flowing in an active way.

It's a real shame too, because the pixel animations are fantastic and the music is boombastic. Too bad the game never really explains how to pull off high profile kills, or trick partygoers into a death trap. If they would have upped the ante and allowed for more freedom, I think this game could have taken the industry by storm. Catch it on a sale if you can, I wouldn't buy this at full price.

Don't take my word for it though, go ahead and check out this hour of gameplay.

https://youtu.be/SCy32mCB8ig

reviewText:
The one word that came to mind that perfectly describes this could-have-been-a-gem of a game's inexcusably dumb design decisions is inane. No not insane, inane. There are some more maps after you beat the game but after I tried the first extra map I had finally had enough. The game is extremely inconsistent in several ways. Overall it has so many nonsensical game flaws that you would think whoever made this was in special needs classes in school. I wanted to like this game pretty bad because it looks and plays awesome, but ultimately it is just not even worth the $6 I spent on it on sale. When it was over I breathed a sigh of relief and looked forward to forgetting the developer's constantly glaring bad mistakes that I experienced the whole time that put a sad sheet over how awesome the game could have been.

+ Awesome graphics/effects
+ Mass murder simulator
+ 80's theme-ish
+ Fun traps
+ Fun gameplay
+ Works great with xbox 360 controller
+ Very fun for a few levels

- Only a few traps per level, sometimes as few as one or two.
- Most traps have a very tiny kill radius or are gone after someone walks into them once.
- Immediately turns into a stabfest. Out of the 40-50 kills needed per level, you will have to get 30-40 of them by stabbing. For the first few levels I didn't care and was having a blast. After that, it got real old real fast because all levels are just tedious, long, drawn out stabfests.
- Killing people means just stabbing, waiting for a cop or medic (who for some stupid reason wear tall white baking hats) to come and cover them up and leave, then stab some more, move around to not get caught or linked to a kill, and that is all there is to the game really.
- FBI agents will sometimes start running after you even though they had no way of linking you to any murders.
- Cops will bust you without proof you killed someone, just because you are standing in their walk path (can be avoided with practice).
- Bouncers will attack you at first site even if you just started the level and just walked close to one. Why? Why me when I am just a party goer like everyone else? Are they psychic and know I will start killing people? Is there a secret APB out to all bouncers to stomp to death anyone fitting your description?
- Bouncers stomp you to death when they catch you. Why?
- The campus party has bouncers. Why? What campus party has ever had bouncers? Let alone the four to six that are on that level. Ignoring the fact that it is insanely stupid to have bouncers at a campus party in the game, why have so many?
- Sometimes you get linked to the murder just because... well just because the game felt like it.
- The music is sub-par at best, and it got so mind jarringly repetitive that I very quickly couldn't stand it and played 95% of the game with my headphones around my neck. The problem is that when you retry a level 20+ times and have to hear the same one-tone one-beat music restart every time you retry, it makes you hate it quickly.

7/10 for a few levels
5/10 otherwise
5.9/10

reviewText: No game has ever had me say, How?" and "What the f**k?" more than Party Hard.\n\nDon't get me wrong
date: the concept is great and the game can be fun to play. I can see why people love it
recommended:
however I found the experience more annoying and frustrating than fun during my playthrough and here's why...

-The line of site is almost completely broken in this game:

Victims and cops can see you and bodies behind objects and walls that should be impossible to see. Not to mention
hoursPlayed:
the game tries to balance this by making their line of sight moderately short range taking away from the fun. I think the game could be much improved with longer lines of sight and improved obstructions of said line of sight. As of now it's pretty much flipping a coin on each kill unless you're totally secluded from everything else.

-Traps and placements are randomized every time the mission starts:

Now this is actually a cool and interesting feature but I'm afraid its a double-edged sword. More than often you find yourself spawning with barely any ways to kill or distract crowds with a near to zip chance of succeeding. Of course
voteText:
there's players who seek this challenge and like to pull it off. I just feel an average player with moderate skill like me is going to find themselves restarting the mission over and over until there's at least one worthy trap.

-Every other map has a totally broken trap/phone call that can clean house hands free with zero work:

This is very unfortunate because maps with traps like these tend to lack good design and are thrown in there like a cheat to skip the mission. It's mind blowing not a single victim/guard cares if your phone call brings people to the party and are obvious threats knocking people out and killing left and right.

-The police/guards make no sense at all in this game
helpfulPercent: especially considering their methods of public safety:\n\nUpon arrival the police almost always run over people killing them instantly. I'm sure most people wouldn't write this off as a bad thing because who cares
votesTotal: I think it's beyond stupid as you can't even use this feature to your advantage like luring crowds into the street and getting the cops to run them over. The swat beat everyone down if they're called but for some reason you get "BUSTED" for being beat down like anyone else. (The people beat down aren't even arrested.) Finally
votesFunny: the guards... These guys beat you down just for showing up. I can understand if they're at the front door serving as a bouncer like in the second mission
commentsCount:
but otherwise it's a dumb mechanic. How would they know if you're invited or not with all the people and partying going on.

-Horrible blame and accusation system:

I can't even state how many times I was busted for doing nothing wrong at all. If anyone at all dies near the player everyone assumes its the player and calls the cops over for an arrest. Countless times I've been walking on the brinks of the map to try ang get away from people dying and cops who are passing by will stop to arrest me for walking away like everyone else. Sometimes it's its not the cops and just random people who will call the cops for no reason. An interesting yet broken feature is the ability for victims to accuse and call cops on other victims. This leads to the most random arrests I've ever seen and it doesn't help the player's experience as it can't really be triggered on purpose similarly to police running over victims...

-Handful of small bugs that aren't "game breaking" but result in the player's death all the time:

Typically
column16:
the cops are supposed to leave and ignore any more crimes the second they have someone over their shoulder or have bagged all the bodies but I've been arrested with people over their shoulder's twice in my time playing. Is it a feature? Possibly. It sure doesn't look like it. These police have pretty broken behavior and do random things they shouldn't more than often.

Conclusion:

Overall the game is fun yes
column17: but success is a crap shoot and mostly RNG. When I say it's RNG I mean RNG... Going back to replay the game with end game knowledge and skill barely helps in this game. The game offers a mediocre story with TERRIBLE voice acting. The only real replay value in this game comes from the steam workshop allowing the player to download other player's missions and play them. Note
column18: there ARE unlockable characters in this game with some really good pros but
column19: they have horrible cons that render them useless. People say this game is a "stealth" game but it really isn't at all.\n\nI would recommend waiting for a sale to pick this game up. I think it's worth a playthrough but isn't an amazing game you'll be playing a lot. Heck
column20: I'll probably forget about this game a week or so from now. I don't mean this in a bad or rude way
column21:
the game just didn't leave a memorable impact on me at all.

Side Note for Hotline Miami fans:

People compare this game to Hotline Miami all the time
column22: but the two are nothing at all alike aside from being a masked killer who cleans house. If you're looking for a good alternative to Hotline Miami 1&2
column23: I would recommend Deadbolt and not this. Deadbolt features a 2D world with one hit kills. It provides better challenge that requires planning very much like Hotline Miami.\n\nFinal Rating: 4/10"

Translates into real-life. 10/10 would play this instead of going to a real-life party.

reviewText:
For some reason I avoided this game for the longest time, and I shouldn't have.

Party Hard takes a really simple premise, adds in metric tons of details and humor, and just runs with it. All of the time I have logged in this game has literally been on Saturday nights with a group of four people at a party. Its great to just pass the controller around and see who can complete the level. Its great fun.

Essentially, you are trying to pick people off one-at-a-time without getting caught. You can brute force stab them. You can use traps, and even items that you find. There is definately a moderately deep layer of strategy that you can use. There is tons of content, achievements, and unlockables.

Pros:
+Artwork is really great.
+Everything occurs on a single screen. No panning or breaks.
+Music is super appropriate, and easy to listen to.
+Simple to learn, impossible to master gameplay.
+Tons of unlockables and levels. Lots to do here. Now I hear there is Workshop support?! Crazy.
+Controller and keyboard support is great. Controls are minimal and easy to reference.
+Lots of throwback references and good humor.

Cons:
-I can't really think of any - except that the voice acting is subpar, but I'll chalk that up to super cheesy.

Totally worth full price, and best played in a group.

reviewText:
Looked fun, got these 80s vibes and a few awards, so I got my hands on this. While the first levels are actually fun to play, the game quickly becomes more and more random, ending whatever plan you have with a stabfest. Ain't nobody got time for traps, since they seem to be working randomly anyway. Stealth system and AI are also random, as you can get linked to a murder for absolutely nothing, which is painfully annoying past a certain level (Miami thing) since you cannot plan anything due to the amount of random, and must resort to either stab everyone as fast as you can, or play stab'n'hide in a corner of the map. Which is sad, since as I said, 80s ambience is well made, soundtrack is decent, but the game as a whole is just boring.


TL;DR: Just go play Hotline Miami.

reviewText:
*******Video Review*********
https://youtu.be/kk-M2Sz_HUQ


-Video Transcript-

If youre gonna have a party, then you better be ready to party hard with all the traditional favors; drinks, dancing, music, knives, poison, bombs, and bears. Ok, maybe you
shouldn't party that hard personally but that's how you do it in Party Hard by Indie Dev Pinoki Games. Party Hard is a game about a man who is fed up with his neighbors
constant partying and he justs wants to get some sleep. However that man is also a brutal psychopath choosing to end the party by any means neccesary without stopping
until going around the country and crashing each party he encounters. You'll enter each party armed with nothing but a knife where the only goal is to kill everyone.
You also have the capability to rig traps, sabatoge environments, pick up other weapons and tools, and also call in support from time to time. Regardless of your approach
you have to be careful and not be seen doing any of these attacks. The overall system works very well with party goers only calling you out if they see you commit the crime,
or walk in on you standing near dead bodies.

The environmental attacks work as a sort of freebie and won't alert people to your pressence but if they see the dead body
they're likely to call the cops which tends to make things more difficult until they leave. If I had one complaint here, it's that I wish there was even more environmental
interaction. With the procedral style level design these objects change position making it interesting with room for replayability, but I still would like to see more to
interact with. What tends to happen is you stab a few victims, hide a few bodies and start activating traps, only to run out and wait for the npc's to break away from the
crowd one by one thus repeating this step over and over. It's still satisfying to single out victims, but the game gets really exciting when you unleash a big attack forcing
the scragglers into other surrounding traps.

That brings me to the overall design and tone. Party Hard is a modern day 16-bit game in a half cocked birds eye view, which definitely brings a comparison to the similar
styled game Hotline Miami. But, where hotline miami was a fast paced shoot & slug fest, Party Hard takes things a bit slower invoking a lot of technical planning and
thinking. I think this is great because rather than be a copy, it's a very different game that will appeal to the same audience. If you enjoyed Hotline Miami, and enjoy
puzzle like stealth then you'll enjoy this. The music will also likely get you pumped and excited as you play. Right away I was bobbing my head and enjoying the music the
moment I started until it was over.

The story was good as well with a recollective style narrative involving a cop and interviewer discussing the path the murderer took. It kept me hooked in and was very well
done with a few twists and decent voice acting. It took me a bit over 7 hours to complete but I'll definitely be playing again to try and get faster times and better
scores.

Overall Party Hard is a game you should play. It has good replayability, the gameplay is smooth and I encountered only a few technical issues. Its gritty story and
violent nature are entertaining and the soundtrack is just awesome. The only negatives are as I mentioned, the enironments could use a bit more interaction, and I would like
to have had more weapon options and traps. With that I'm giving Party Hard an A-. This is definitely one to pick up and I wouldn't be surprised if there is a second one.

I'm Conner and thanks for watching my review. For more gaming videos, hit subscribe or check out UberCrit.com. But for now, here's a closer look at Party Hard.

reviewText: A lot of people have been saying it's like Hotline Miami, which you'd think is a pretty positive comparison, and I'd say it is. It's more lateral in comparison, not much better or worse but altogether different. You're supposed to kill people, you die a lot, and there's situations you'll get into which are complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. It's much more chill, though. You have a lot more incentive to lurk around and see the flow of things, keep it cool and wait things out and plan your attack. It's the inverse of most of Hotline's mechanics, with a lot of the same mode of delivery.\n\nI liked it, and I had fun playing it. That's all I really know how to say.

reviewText: Very fun game that's all about creating chaos. The premise is simple: you're a psychopath on an insane cross-country killing spree. You have to kill everyone at each party you attend without being arrested or dying yourself. You can stab people, or kill them in groups with various amusing traps. The core gameplay is super fun, though the game can occasionally get frustrating when you get stuck on some of the harder levels. And the difficulty is inconsistent, with a few levels feeling almost impossible at times. Still, as your skills grow, you'll appreciate some of the subtle strategies more and more. After beating the regular campaign, you can play another half dozen bonus levels that are wacky variations on the regular levels, and you can also unlock four additional characters, each of which have their own restrictions and extra powers that significantly change the nature of the game. It took me about ten hours to beat all the regular levels, but I feel like there's probably another 20-30hrs for completionists who want to beat every party with every character. Some of the combinations are incredibly challenging. So yeah, if you're looking for something a little different, where you're the unapologetic bad guy, check this out.

reviewText:
Party Hard is easily the most baffled I've been by a game's positive reception since Sir You Are Being Hunted. Though this is by no means as bad as SYABH. It's just not very good. It fundamentally misunderstands both the stealth genre and Hotline Miami giving you a hodgepodge that doesn't really do justice to either. There's so many basic design mistakes that playing this ends up being a frustrating experience rather than an elating one. And it's a shame because the concept is absolutely brilliant.

There's the components of a good game here, and it's very pretty, but levels are too long for the ease of failure, mechanics are poorly explained, there's no indication of how far an NPC can see which prevents effective stealth, it's buggy - I've had the AI glitch out on 2/6 runs, and there's not enough different mechanics leaving very little variation in how parties play. The game feels like someone took a game jam prototype and expanded the number of levels to full game length without thinking through what needed to be added in order to accommodate that much content.

It would take so little for this to become an enthusiastic recommendation, but Party Hard is unrefined to the point where it overshadows all merits that the game has. There's no reason to pick this up, I'm hesitant to even give a 'get this when it's in a bundle' recommendation.

reviewText: A much different kind of stealth game. It's not really about remaining unseen and preventing calls to the cops, but instead more about making sure nobody knows you're the killer. You need to use traps intelligently, be patient, ambush people, hide bodies...and also flee the scene, dance, or change clothes so nobody suspects anything. What I didn't suspect was the well-voiced cutscenes in between each map detailing the story. They were a great addition to what would otherwise be a pretty fun semi-procedurally generated game.

reviewText:
In Party Hard you play as someone who is really tired of the neighbors having loud parties.
Instead of calling the cops, you decide it’s a better idea to pay these parties a visit and kill everyone by using your knife!

Party Hard is a tactical strategy game created by Pinoki Games during a Game Jam and the team is backed up by TinyBuild. The game feels like an 80's game experience with the synthesizer music, flashing neon colors and pixel-art although the game is a true 90's horror slasher game.
Party hard follows a series of killings at parties throughought the United States of America, dialogued by a detective called Mr John West who will do the narrative about these Party-hard-killings.
The game has 12 levels to beat and some of them are quite hard to break, just like the old NES games back in the day.

Your main goal within Party Hard is to not get caught while you pick off victims one by one.
The only things you can use to your advantage are for instance traps within the environment, special guests by dialing a phone number and weapons/items found inside briefcases or  poison provided by dark merchants with creepy jackets.
Your opponents are the Cops, FBI, SWAT-team, bouncers, party people (who can notice your mass murders) and Mario the plumber/carpenter who locks off areas by blocking windows of trapdoors so you can't easily flee from the police forces.

I really can recommend Party Hard to anyone who is looking for a challenge to beat, to get creative on a bloodbath, pixel-art, synt-wave music, references to classic retro movies, games etc., dancing bears or simply if you like to Party Crash!
If the game is on sale then you really should pick up this title and give it a dance!

reviewText:
Stumbled upon it due to a greenlight review video by the - Jesse Cox (the Big JC). Thus it's the first indie title i've bought at launch.

It's an interesting and slightly addictive mayhem game, where you try to slaughter pixels while avoiding the pixel police and those pesky loitering witnesses.

Controls are straightfoward and responsive if you know they exist (a hint about sprint would have been nice). Check the control setup page and then wade in, the rest is explained in pop ups. Trial and error your way through the first couple of levels, then you'll be partying hard in no time at all.

The art style is pleasing, the music is good and not overpowering. Worth a space in your game library.

reviewText:
Party Hard is one of those 'Hidden Gem' type of games of 2015

You play a guy who just can't get any sleep over partys playing loud music through the night.

But he's had about enough, and decides to kill everyone, but he doesn't stop there, he gets a bloodlust going across the US to kill as many people and different kinds of partys.

To kill people you can use traps or just use your knife, after murdering them you can hide there bodies in dumpsters for example.

What I will say is you may rage when playing as the levels get increasingly harder the further you get, but that's what I liked. I liked the challenge of trying to kill as many people using different strategies after each retry.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I played it for 7 hours straight when I first bought it, and I don't even to that for AAA games anymore.

The price is a bit much for the content it has but I would recommend to get it on sale.
They will be adding workshop later on so that's good for people with great level ideas.

Overall it's an 8/10 Very Good from me.
