reviewText:
Go and literally kill a party because you can't sleep. Finally a psychopath I can relate to!

In all seriousness though, I'd queue this game for one of my GOTYs. It has fitting music and fun gameplay, though, I will have to give it a small minus because it reuses certain traps over and over again, even if they don't really fit into the scenario (Why are there bubble gum machines everywhere?), which, thankfully, the game makes up with a large variety of different levels and level-themes.

Even as someone that isn't a big fan of pixel graphics, I did enjoy them in this game since they were usually clean, spot-on and somewhat high-res.

The story has a nice twist, though, it's mostly just giving you a bit of back-story to what you're doing. Unfortunately, none of the events in said back-story have any affect on how the game plays out. (The police doesn't start re-inforcing parties in which 40 people have already been killed, the game tells you about vigilante-mobs roaming the streets and taking the problems into their own hands, though, you'll never meet one of them. Neither does the story ever crack down on the laziness the police officers seem to have.)

Party Hard also features several characters which you can unlock , which, as the game says, you get through getting achievements, for example completing the game. They're obviously supposed to get some replayability into the game, though, unfortunately, one of the characters I unlocked was only usable in a single mission and the other was somewhat useless, since it was broken to a certain point. (By disabling the ability to interact with most objects, you're unable to go into areas such as the pool, therefore, you couldn't access certain areas). But even if you don't have problems with that, there's still the issue of replaying the same levels you had already visited again, in the exact same state By the way, without the ability to interact with most objects... Good ♥♥♥♥ing luck beating miami party lol)

reviewText: The premise alone can be summed up quickly enough to make people laugh and want to try the game, which is a pretty great achievement in itself. And the game actually follows up with a solid experience. It's genuinely fun to blow people up, poison them, run them over, frame them when the cops show up, and stuff their bodies into sewer grates. Once you're used to it, the game itself is fun to play.\n\nBut that's the thing, you have to be used to it. After the tutorial, the game immediately throws you into a party of sixty people and lets you loose. There's no learning curve" quite as much as there is being thrown in wholesale

reviewText:
This game is a sleath puzzler that throws in some very fun/fustrating  random events in the same level.   While it's pretty short from start to the end  story wise you'll come back to it just to murder people in different ways also there's twitch voting system that allows people to vote on the vauge events could be anything from a bunch of people showing up to a dancing bear to..... Sharknato.     It's replayablity comes from entertaining events that come about from drug busts to robberies to another murder coming around to swat teams the different levels themes also adds to this....

The cons,  There isn't enough traps changes to make it a trap only killing game  and if you not into a game that can be very hard and will restart the whole level on you when you die.... and you will die or get busted from the cops a plenty but beating that one level without leaving a single body is Super satifying.  Oh and the music is party music looped over and over and over again ... granted it is awesome to listen at first   I wish there was more then one track per level cuz it gets annoying after the the 10th time you come back cuz you want that perfect body count.


Overall this game is worth it!     bonus the creators said they wont' do DLC  everything will be free from here on out.

reviewText:
Yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes!

When I had a Commodore-64 there was a cheap knock-off of the Friday the 13th" franchise.  I know that I probably used "Fast Hack'em" to get a copy.  ANd I wouldn't have paid for it.  But d*mn it was fun!

This game reminded me of my high-school days.  It's one of the few retro games that I think actually captured the spirit of the 1980s.

This game is surprising deep in the amount of strategy required to succeed.  Sure
date: you can just go on a rampage and start killing everything in sight.  But to do so successfully
recommended: without being caught -- therein is the rub.\n\nLike many games
hoursPlayed:
I could do without the plot.  I don't particularly care about why this guy is killing a sh*t-ton of people.  Though I do think it's pretty funny that basically he starts his killing spree because his neighbors won't stop partying and keep the noise down so he can get some sleep.

There is a ton of humor in the game -- it's funny sometimes to watch how the protagonist (who I guess is more anti-hero than protagonist) how he manages to kill people.  And perhaps the most satisfying elements is that you can take a hatchet to many of those hard-core gamers who live in their mothers' basement.

More than enough laughs here.  Hit the Lamborghini so that it runs over everyone standing at the entrance to the club.  Make sure that nobody see you duck out the window with that corpse.

And who truly know that dumpsters could hide so many bodies?  Nevermind
voteText: I don't want to know if you already had an estimation of that...\n\n$13 is about right for this game.  There is a lot of content
helpfulPercent: a ton of replay value
votesHelpful: And enough intrigue and strategy to make the idle moments of a Sunday afternoon pass with a high degree of content and satisfation.\n\nAs everything I write and review -- I am a casual gamer.  I have a life
commentsCount: and I work hard to pay off soul-crushing student loan debt.  I evaluate games based on whether I would purchase them again because they help me espace the real work.\n\nBuy this game.  Yes

reviewText:
Party Hard is a pixel graphic strategy/stealth-em-up game. The idea of the game is you're a guy trying to get some sleep, your neighbours are having a house party, so at 3am you go around there and kill them all, even the DJ. From that you go on an anti-party psychopathic rage around America crashing parties and killing everyone in your path.

There's small (skippable) cut scenes between levels which help set the narritave, but aren't important to watch if you just fancy killing 40 odd people on a rooftop party instead.

The gameplay itself can be quite slow, but not to the point of where it's boring, to me it makes it feel more like the character you're controlling is cool, calm and collected; although it can be annoying when trying to outrun Police/FBI/Bouncers. There's a sprint bar which depletes *very* quickly, a slight shame if you're waiting to speed up your murderous rampage. Different 'events' can and do happen per level which can be a help or hindrance. SWAT might turn up, FBI might turn up, Pest exterminators might even turn up. Level design is nice and the mechanics are good, I think the odd thing could do with a slight tweak, but it still perfoms solidly.

The soundtrack to the game is pretty decent, and will end up staying in your head for hours after you've exited out of the game. The sound effects suit the game to a tee.

At the time of writing this I had completed the 'main' story within 7 hours, that's with several restarts on one level, so I suspect it could be completed within 5-6 hours. There's scope for replayablilty with extra unlockable characters with different abilities and probably even better a level editor and steam workshop thus allowing for arguably endless playability.


All in all, it's a decent, humourous game; a solid little indie title which I would recommend to anyone.

reviewText:
Brutally murdered a girl in a bathroom at a house party. When the police showed up to investigate, they immediately arrested the black guy and covered up the body, then left. Everyone then partied on.

Detonated a bomb on the dance floor at a rooftop party. SWAT teams were called to scene and proceeded to beat up the surviving party goers, then left. Everyone then partied on.

Poisoned the punch bowl at a party. When a girl fell dead to ground on the dance floor next to the black bouncer, the mob on the dance floor beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of him and had him arrested. Everyone then partied on.

Best celebration of American culture since Postal

reviewText:
Party Hard is an interesting, silly, and cheap game.  It is a lot of fun if you enjoy murdering people, you psychopath.
This game is is seriously demented.  The whole premise is that you must kill everyone at a party.  Stab them, push them, burn them, poison them: kill them without getting busted.

The game is cheap, that is low-quality.  Many of the levels resort to you standing in one spot waiting for someone stupid enough to walk by you.  While the levels certainly look very different, the game play is largely the same on each level.  Unlocked characters help to relieve the monotony and improve re-playability.  The graphics are as ugly as the game is perverted.  The music feels uninspired.  While the game draws on the same nostalgic vibe as Hotline Miami it fails to deliver the same level of charisma.

This title may not have a greatness, an everlasting quality, but it is most certainly fun.  It's silly, it's dark, it's crazy.   I have an open request for a workshop level: How about I play Ted Cruz at a Donald Trump rally?
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
There's honestly nothing I can say negatively about Party Hard. The game looks and feels flawless. The campaign length is perfect, while adding extra modes upon completion to extend the replay value. There is a story which drives you to find out more about the main character, which is very rare to find at all, let alone being as properly executed as it is in this game. I cannot sing enough praises about this game. Pixel art done right. A gorgeous soundtrack for each and every party scene. Completely worth the price and time put into it.

Even if you buy this game for nothing else, you should definitely buy it for its catchy soundtrack. I beat this game over six months ago and I'm still singing these tunes.

For those who don't know how this game works, you are a man who is tired of the constant partying that you've heard throughout the night, and instead of calling the police, you decide to take it into your own hands and start slaying at the party. Literally. Your objective: kill every single person at the party without getting busted by the police. You are given many tools and environmental traps to get it done. Hide the bodies, or leave them out for the cops to find, the choice is yours.

The Steam version has a feature that is not yet (as of writing this) available to other versions, which is Twitch chat integration. This allows your own Twitch community to help and hinder you as you play. Maybe they'll fumigate a room for you. Maybe they'll send in a killer bear. Hopefully you've been kind to them, because this feature adds a new dimension to an already immaculate game.

You can watch my full playthrough here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MlgmW4D0Bho&list=PLWNmvYZnVvRsEm_UEIgG_DpNhKQGrFd5z&index=1

reviewText:
Party Hard is a hard game to describe.  It has a Hotline Miami vibe with the look of the game and the soundtrack, but it's gameplay is slow and calculated.   For me, trial and error plays a big part in successfully clearning a level.  So, if you are into stealth games, and this looks like it tickels your fancy, I would suggest giving it a shot.  Here are some quick pros and cons.

-PROS-

-Original idea
-Pretty good 80's soundtrack
-Sense of discovery- the game DOES NOT hold your hand
-Satisfying to finally clear a hard level

-CONS-

-Bad voice acting (IMO)
-Occaisional Bugs.  This is not a HUGE deal, but sometimes, bodies don't properly drop off of the side of buildings, police dude gets stuck, etc.  This game came out with no early access (which is awesome), so this is forgiveable.   I'm sure they will fix these (small) issues.

reviewText:
Very zen! It was oddly relaxing waiting to pounce on your next victim.

Gripes:
-Fustrating to start the entire level all over again especially when you spent 15 minutes and almost down to the last several people.
-I swear people from the other side of the map 'saw' me killing in most of the one 'room' maps (like beach party) thus ending a great run.
-Story is flimsy, but love the motive.
-I wish there was a better indicator of who saw you.
-BOUNCERS.
-Your character is not exactly fit aka the sprint meter fades pretty quickly.
- and the biggest gripe, you have to learn the hard way of what traps and events do. Most of them accidently resulting in your death.

Overall, with the gripes, it was a relaxing experience. This is definately a game that tests your paitence and rewards a perfect opportunity and a quick knife. Would love to see a speed run of this.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Party Hard is a game about killing all the party goers so you can go back to sleep ;)

You basically wander around a pixellated party and try to cause as much damage without anyone noticing what you're doing and calling for the police. Poisoning the drinks, breaking the oven, knocking down trees, setting fire to the loudspeakers or outright stabbing people. But you can't just go on a rampage in the middle of the dance floor because you'll be quickly overwhelmed by the party goers. You have to be smart about it, try to utilise the enviroment to cause a panic or pick off lonely targets snuggling in some bedroom. Hell, once people start dropping from that poison you poured in the drinks maybe theyll blame some random unlucky dude and the police will take care of him for you.

There's a lot to do and you'll need to think fast because people are constantly on the move and one wrong move can lead to an arrest or getting your ♥♥♥ kicked by the bouncers.

It takes around 10-15 minutes to beat a level but you're practically guaranteed to be restarting each one a few times until you get the feel for it (or just manage not to screw up).

The game keeps things fresh by randomising some elements of each party like the traps or certain rooms. To top it off there are random events happening now and again where a bunch of bikers may crash your party to kick someones ♥♥♥. Another time the feds might get a wind of you and start patrolling the party, or a dancing bear might show up to bust some moves on the dance floor.

There are two problems with it though. For one - the tutorial is really kinda useless. The game drops some strategy hints around parties in the form of newspapers you can stop to read, but it lacks any sort of introduction on how to do well. You either have to discover stuff on your own or watch a youtube video of someone playing to realise for example that the 'listen' button allows you to judge if anyone will hear you stabbing a person. There are a few simple gameplay elements that are not really explaind very well but are very important if you want to do well and not end up frustrated.

The other thing is that the game is kinda short. There are around 13 (or so) levels and I finished them all in around 6 hours. The groundwork is there and I could see the game having double the amount of levels and giving the player more incentive to replay them with the other characters.

I still recommend it, its great fun, maybe wait for a sale though.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Quite different game indeed. I love the soundtrack, thought it gets kind of repetative after a while with only one track per level.
Also the NPCs seem to bug out, and just stop doing whatever after a while. Often they get stuck in a crowd at a place on the level and don't move. When this happens, events doesn't seem to load either.

I do like the Twitch interaction that is included, that people can vote on whatever happens. I wish there was a bit more varation since the same thing seems to pop up quite often.

The art style is something I really like, I think it works for the game.

If the bugs are fixed, and some more varation in soundtrack and voting features are implemented I can recommend this game. Quite chill and fun game, but also quite challenging.

reviewText:
I bought Party HARD for Halloween and thoroughly enjoyed it, but it's definitely not for everyone.


The Good:

The premise and gameplay of Party HARD is chock full of dark humor.  Remember Mortal Kombat back when it was satisfied with being silly (punching people two stories, people exploding and having dozens of hearts and stomachs fall out, dropping arcade machines on people, etc.) instead of serious?  It's like that.

While it uses pixel art, it's not because the developers can't draw and won't hire someone that can, as is often the case.  It's actually good.  Each party is uniquely themed, and there is a lot of variety in how partygoers look.

The music is memorable, and I liked it.  I think the voice acting was pretty good for it to have been done by one person.

Most of the time the AI behavior is surprisingly good, and amusing.  Individuals choose between fight or flight based on the number of partygoers around them, and their behavior.  Paniced characters will often wrongly accuse others, usually the one nearest the body when they spot it (as it should be).  Large numbers of frightened partiers will often move together like a herd.


The Bad:

The funny setup is squandered on a serious generic slasher flick plot.  The cinema scenes clash badly with the gameplay.  They should have gone with something more fitting, like the poor guy moving after killing his noisy neighbors, only to keep having the same thing happen time and time again.

Another thing that clashes with the humor is the surprisingly high difficulty.  I find laughing and feeling frustrated to be mutually exclusive.

For the most part, the levels are badly designed.  It's easy to blame this on procedural generation, but procedural generation can generate well designed levels (e.g. the original X-COM).  It's just harder to program.

The real culprits behind the bad level design:
high population density
lack of cover
lack of variety
While it makes sense for some parties to be packed, not all of them should be.  Anyone familiar with stealth games should understand why this is a problem, but it interacts with several other problems to make things much worse.  By itself, the excessive number of enemies on each level primarily inflates play time, without adding any enjoyment to the game.

You can't save in the middle of a level.  Due to the glut of enemies on each level, if you do get caught, you may have lost a half hour or more of progress.  This is the primary cause of the excessive difficulty.

With so many eyes on you there better be lots of places to hide, pick of stragglers, and dispose of bodies…  Well, there aren't.

The ninja was a great idea for a character with a very different play style.  Unfortunately, due to there being eyes everywhere, placed arbitrarily at the start of the level, and little or no cover, he is almost impossible to play.  It's not unusual to be spotted as soon as the level starts.

Your character is poorly equipped to deal with the overpopulation problem.  You can dance (and risk getting beaten almost to death) or use freshly killed bodies to scatter partiers, but this is repetitive, and provides poor control over victim movement.

You might expect an unabashed murder simulator to provide you with many items you can use to dispatch victims in creative ways.  Prepare to be disappointed.  On most levels you're going to be stuck with the variation on a knife (knife, sword, or chainsaw) your character starts with.  On some levels you may find a knife with a slightly longer reach (i.e. a sword) if you don't already start with one.  The lack of ranged attacks feels especially strange.  The only remaining items that can be used for killing are (time) bombs and poison.  The rest (extra clothes, running sneakers, smoke grenade, and stun bomb) just make your job slightly easier.  Everything except the sword is limited use, and there is usually only one item per level, which makes some items, like the extra clothes, almost worthless.  The ninja can slowly regenerate smoke bombs, at least.

There is considerably more variety in ‘traps’.  I use the term traps loosely, because I lack a good word for “object or feature that can become dangerous in the right circumstances”.  Each level will start with quite a few.  Sadly, there still aren't enough to keep the game feeling fresh.  About midway through the game you will have seen all the traps there are.  It doesn't help that most traps are single-use (forcing you to rely on your much more boring knife most of the time), and many have the same effect (namely exploding after a short delay).  The traps could have been made so much more interesting by allowing you to place or move some of them, and set up chain reactions.

Continuing with the theme of lack of variety, its a good thing I enjoyed the music, since there's so little of it.  The same tracks get used for party after party.

I mentioned that most of the time the AI behavior is good.  Well, the rest of the time it is very bad.  The worst problem is when a body is found and someone calls the cops, you are frequently known to be the murderer even if you were never spotted, and the police automatically know where you are and are impossible to hide from.  The police also move faster than you, so are usually impossible to get away from.  Less serious problems include silly behavior like the drug dealer calling the cops, and the firemen, handyman, and medics not caring about you killing people in front of them.

Despite having the graphics and sound options PC users expect, there is no way to remap the keys.

There are bugs unlocking the characters (specifically The Butcher) and achievements (most of them).  They seem to only work if you perform the task in the expected way (see Youtube videos), instead of merely meeting the requirement.

reviewText:
This game has an interesting concept and visual style, but it's ruined by its terrible execution of almost everything it tries for. You are required to kill every single person in every level, and after you've used your paltry handful of one-time use environmental kills, at which point the only strategy becomes waiting in a room for someone to walk in, slitting them up, and waiting for the cops to leave. Rinse and repeat no less than 11 million times.

It also has a very serious story told by conversations between a cop investigating the killings and some other guy (don't know who he is, but some not-so-subtle hints lead me to believe that it's the killer). Unfortunately, the dialogue is awash in awful cliche, and the voice acting sounds like a teenager trying to emulate Sin City's narrator.

If you want to play a pink and purple tinted pixel-art gama about a murderous psychopath, play Hotline Miami instead, as it beats this game in every single respect.

reviewText:
I didn't have much prior knowledge of the game on purchase, so I generally went with the notion it's a stealth arcade killer. Party Hard is basically a mixed twist of features, both good and bad. There is also a story, of sorts, which throws a few surprises your way which have no impact on the gameplay, other than to provide a shaky narrative to connect different mass murders with each other. Overall, it's a fun diversion for a few hours, but despite the replayability factors, it's not polished, memorable or a game I'd expect myself returning to at a later date.

THE POSITIVE:

+ The game can be challenging despite it's simple appearance and gameplay.
+ The game will definitely keep you on your toes on your initial playthrough due to the amount of unexpected random events and occurences.
+ Easy to understand core mechanics and get into the game after the initial tutorial level.
+ Despite the seemingly simple premise of letting yourself loose upon an unsuspecting crowd, the game does take some tact and planning to complete most of the levels, barring the fortunate accident in which all the random resources scattered about the map provide enough coverage to wipe out all the party-goers.
+ Level Editor for player made content, providing more bang for the buck.
+ Apparently Twitch compatibility, but I am not an user so I can't really say much about that.

The Negative:

- Basically, the AI is a dunce. As some have already mentioned, corpse pickups don't respond to player mayhem in any way and you can literally toss people off roofs or chuck them into barbeques or rotating steel fans without anyone so much as batting an eye. The parties will keep on going despite the player leaving a trail of bodies in their wake, and sometime the only response the player's actions elicit from the locals is 'Can't someone clean this up, this is killing my party buzz?'
- The techno soundtrack might not be everybody's cup of tea. I personally found myself toning down the music since it got to be a nuisance in prolonged maps.
- The player characters all run like they had lead weights on. This is to counteract the law enforcement game of tag the player faces if they happen to be caught redhanded in their wanton carnage. Basically, fleeing from the police is impossible, other than abusing the pathfinding by putting as many turns between yourself and the boys in blue as possible or taking one of the shortcuts in the maps, which brings me to the next item...
- The shortcuts, for some miraculous reason are always expended if you're being chased by law enforcement officers while you take them. A Mario expy will pop out and hammer them out of commission, depriving you their use for the rest of the mission. Granted, this is more a nuisance rather than a real shot in the leg- if you're already doing horribly, you're liable to restart anyway.
- At the time of playing, I encountered several bugs ranging from broken features to cosmetic glithes to a random slow-down.

reviewText:
Party Hard or Hardly Party? I'm still not sure.
TL:DR - wait until it's in a bundle

I played the first half of Party Hard's missions with great enthusiasm; the music was funky and the artwork engaging. Although the play time of each level seemed to stretch more than necessary - I put that down to lack of skill level. Once I picked it up again the next day, I was disappointed to find that the gameplay quickly became repetitive as the mechanics brutally punish risk. I found myself shying away from special items and resorting to walking back and forth between secluded spots to kill people. This is by far the dullest way to achieve the end result but at least it worked. It's quite the opposite of Hotline Miami's twitch reaction play style that some may be familiar with.

Once I decided I simply wanted to finish the main story and be done with it, I couldn't help but pick out other issues. The most grating is the narration between levels which I'm sure looked good on paper but seems to lower the professionalism of the entire title. That combined with the 'twist ending' is enough of a motivation to turn off the cutscenes altogether.

On the whole, I don't think this game is worth the £10 I paid for it. Even with the new levels, I don't imagine the core gameplay has improved. If anyone with more patience than I can advise me otherwise, please do so.

reviewText:
This game is fun to play, however it seems to be lacking in both features and the amount of testing already done on the gameplay. One such example of where things didn't seem to work as intended is where I was no where near any dead bodies and hadn't been seen killing anyone but for some reason got arrested.

I feel that the body guards that are scattered around are irritating as hell as well and feel there needs to be a better way of getting rid of them. Certain levels lack interactivity in terms of traps and seem to rely on you somehow managing to off people one by one in other rooms or out of sight.

I feel that a suspicion meter would make more sense in terms of whether or not theyaccuse you of being the killer (with someone seeing you stab someone filling it up, but someone seeing you next to a dead body as maybe a quarter of the bar, just as an example). This would also go down over time without suspicious acts so as to not penalise players for messing up early on but then doing really well towards the end.

Also, so far the two characters i've played have been exactly the same in every way except cosmetically. I feel it would be appropriate to add more characters and give them special abilities or traits, such as the main hero being able to change masks or something to reduce suspicion, maybe another character who's faster or has more stamina than the other characters and etc. etc.

Overall, enjoying it but finding it rather frustrating when i'm getting arrested for stupid things such as being seen near an already discovered dead body.

Will give 3/5, hoping that certain features get more polish and it becomes a lot less frustrating to play.

reviewText:
Beaten (all 12 missions) - 10 Hours

Keep this Party Going

Party hard is a puzzle game whereby you must kill everyone at a party that takes place on a single screen (40-60 people on average) without being seen.  You accomplish this by your knife and evironmental interactions.  You also must hide the bodies so nobody gets wise of what you are doing.  The levels are also partially randomly generated and the behavior of the people at the party always differs.

The game LOOKS a lot like Hotline Miami"
date: but dont make the assumption it is the same type of game. This is a much more slow-paced game where you have to decide who to take out next. Picking the right victims and the best times and using all the resources available to you is key.\n\nThe game is really quite fun and well made. My only real gripes are some of the voice acting

reviewText:
Wonderful game! The music is fantastic and I really enjoy the pixel art as well, particularly in cutscenes.

Party Hard follows a series of murders carried out by a man whose neighbors had a crazy party one night. All he wanted was some sleep. Once he popped, he couldn't stop, and the murders continued at parties all over the US, gaining him attention from the police and fans. There is a story, pieces of which are revealed after each level's completion. Each level includes traps which can be set off to kill (make horses buck and kill passersby, make outhouses mysteriously tip over onto a sleeping victim, rig speakers to explode, etc). There are also devices you can use to kill, like stun bombs, smoke grenades, big ol' swords, and more.

New levels and characters have been added since the game's release. Plenty of cool achievements to try for, maps (including Vegas and Halloween party maps, among other intereting venues) to enjoy, and party-goers to kill.

The creator is very nice and can communicte with you via Twitter. He retweeted a few of my achievements.

The game is indeed a bit like Hotline Miami, but with more of a stealthy nature. That's how I played Hotline anyway (usually hiding instead of rushing in).

reviewText:
Buggy and tedious. Never have I played a game where you play as a killer and yet feel helpless against you victims. There tons of helpless victims that run at mach 10 to call the police to hunt you down, and you're stuck with trundling along at a snail's pace. The only way to safely beat any level is to tediously kill and dispose of bodies one at a time.

Final straw for me was when I beat the penultimate level and, after killing the last victim, my character just stood there instead of performing the end-of-level dance. This was after my ability to pick up bodies or activate traps broke halfway through the level.

Soundtrack consists of looping dance music that slowly grows annoying after multiple deaths. Save your money.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Buaw-s-GzfM

This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to watch
if you are looking for a more in-depth review.

Party Hard is a 2d pixel top down Slasher game, where you use stealth and guile to complete your mission. The music is decent, but a lot of the songs sounded similar.

Gameplay;
There is a sense of progression, as new characters and options open up to you as you  forge through the game. The game is fairly simplistic, and uses a point system. This would have been ideal to have a leader-board, but unfortunately you can only compete with yourself. Your character attempts to navigate a map and kill all of the party-goers
without being seen. You are able to sneak around and hide bodies, but the stealth aspect is hampered by a lack of places for the character to hide, such as in the shadows or in  a closet. Killings are done on a line of sight basis, which can be interesting, as you are able to pin killings on others if they are the first seen by the body. Stealth becomes
more of a puzzle strategy, in figuring out how to kill everyone without getting caught.

Story;
The story is told in a third person manner, listening to a cop talk about the killings. Overall I enjoyed the story, and wanted to find out what was going to happen. The story gives the game a cops and robbers feel, which makes the conquest of completing levels even more sweet.

Summary;
The game is not perfect, it does have its' suspension of disbelief issues, such as the zombies that run around and need to be killed, but the cops don't attack them. It is a  basic hide and seek game, with a line of sight kill mechanic and a puzzle feel, rather than a pure stealth game or slasher. The gameplay was decent, however, and though it could be rather repetitive, I enjoyed it well enough. I can recommend this game, though just barely...

Thanks for your viewership and support; for more videos click here:
http:/www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

reviewText:
A pretty fun game for what is a simple concept; kill everyone on screen.  Use environmental traps, hide bodies, outrun the cops and move around each level in full sight, but hidden.  It's a great concept and I think the graphics, music and simple controls really make it a fun experience.  At first I assumed it was similar to Hotline Miami ans in some minor ways it is, but it's certainly not as frantic and the real similarity is in visual style and music...not in gameplay.

The story isn't very interesting at all, but the gameplay is pretty much spot on and it's a very addictive and fun game.  It's rarely cheap and if you fail a level then it's usually due to some mistake you have made.  Most of the time this mistake is not taking your time and trying to kill someone at the wrong time. I was guilty of this often, though you want just one more turn" until you get that satisfaction when you complete a level.

There's potential for replayability with the ability to use different characters
date: each having their own particular skill.  Unfortunately the repetitive gameplay means that going back to do it all again with other characters can seem a bit pointless.  Playing through the entire story is good enough and it doesn't really need 20 hours of content.\n\nAfter failure
recommended: the level is randomised.  This means you cannot learn the layout of a level and practice to perfect it.  This could be a bad thing for some players
hoursPlayed: but it actually adds to the challenge.  I never found the random levels I was given to be either too easy or too hard.  They are all challenging in their own way.\n\nParty Hard is a nice take on the stealth genre and is a nice change of pace.  There's perhaps not enough content to justify a full price purchase.  Get it on sale and you will have enough to entertain you for a dozen hours or so.  Nice gameplay
voteText: fitting music and enough of a challenge without being ridiculously frustrating."

reviewText:
Quick Breakdown: A stealth game where you play as a man who just wants to sleep, so he decides to murder everyone who is out partying. It’s a fun premise, but the game suffers from some shortcomings, chief among them how unclear many elements of the gameplay are.
Length: 6-8 hours (Main game)
Genre: Stealth / Action / Murder-Sim
Score: 5.5/10
Review Date: 2016-01-04

Full Review: A friend of mine told me about a game where you play as a serial killer, and that was enough to sell me on it. Sadly, Party Hard wasn’t able to deliver on that as well as I’d hoped. (It didn’t help that I originally had it compared to Hotline Miami, which is a very different game).

The game offers very little in ways of tutorial or how mechanics work. As such, most of the gameplay must be determined via trial and error, and even after having completed the game, I still don’t know how some mechanics work. Mind you, trial and error isn’t per se a bad thing for a game, but Party Hard doesn’t implement it as well as it should. Please, allow me to elaborate.

You play as a man who just wants to get some sleep, and since a loud bunch of party goers are preventing that, you grab your knife and decide to kill everyone at the party. If you’re spotted, the police will be called, upon which they will arrive shortly to arrest you. You move much slower than cops do, so you can’t outrun them, save for if you take a secret passage to evade arrest.

You knife will be your main method of murder and mayhem, but you can (and must) also dispatch using various traps strewn about your environment; which range from poisoning food, setting a bear trap, lighting a room on fire, and rigging things to explode. That probably sounds like a lot of fun, but the execution wavers.

The traps scattered throughout a level, as well as the number of people and their behaviour, are semi-random. This is a two edged sword. On the one hand, it helps create more variety and replayability; on the other, for a game that makes you learn from your mistakes, this makes trial and error sometimes untenable, as things will not play out the same way on your next attempt, were you to fail the previous one. The game is oftentimes too unpredictable for its own good. While it’s fun when a cop decides to arrest a random civilian, or the party goers proceed to beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of a random guest, it’s infuriating to spend 15 minutes in a level, only to have it ruined by a partier randomly beating the ♥♥♥♥ out of you.

This problem is further compounded by the fact that levels take a long time, and the gameplay is very slow. Again, neither things that are per se problems, but when you’re killed by something you couldn’t reasonably predict, it’s aggravating to have to redo a 20 minute level from the beginning. I understand that as a stealth game Party Hard isn’t going to play at a breakneck speed, but it would still be behooved to move a little faster, as even when sprinting, you’re character is still slow as hell.

Not to mention that you exert almost no control over the behaviour of your intended victims, so you must wait for them to move near a trap, or to an isolated area, so that you can kill them without anyone else seeing you. Your influence extends no further than you dancing awkwardly, which will randomly either repel or attract people from you, sometimes both at once. The unpredictability and unreliability make it nigh useless most of the time. This is the key reason why levels take as long as they do, you must patiently play a long waiting game for the right opportunity to strike, lest someone calls in a 1-8-7.

The game uses a pixel art style of graphics, and while they do a passable job, they just don’t grip me much at all. On the bright side, the music is better, though ultimately not very memorable either; it’s at least enough to be entertaining at times while playing.

The game has a basic story about the protagonist murderer and the cop who tried to catch him, but it’s predictable and uninteresting, and features so-so voice acting.

The game will probably take in the neighborhood of 6-8 hours to complete. I pumped in about 8, but it should’ve been less, as I had a few levels that glitched out on me at the end, thus requiring me to replay the entire level again. (Specifically I killed all the victims, and even though my counter read it as 50/50, the victory animation didn’t trigger, and the game wouldn’t progress at all).

This all works together to hinder what could be a really great game, but instead is just an okay game; I hesitate to recommend the game, but I know it’ll have its niche audience that it’ll appeal to. Still, if you think you might be part of that audience, it might still be worth a shot, but I’d recommend waiting for a sale.

reviewText:
Surprisingly fun!  You just sneak around and try to kill everyone at the party without getting caught.  Works great on my Alienware Alpha (i7) with Windows 10 on my 1080p TV, with my Xbox 360 controller.  It launches initially with a lower resolution that doesn't fill the scree, but then you just alter that in settings and now you are full screen at 1080.  It even uses AlienFX to control the color lights on the system :) .

The game is rather easy, but you get caught a lot.  I only found 2 levels to be particularly challenging.  Generally if you are just a little patient, you can get to everyone.  You can also dance (hold A on gamepad), which irritates people around you so you can get them to separate and then go kill them when they are alone.

I find it a rather fun game that I keep wanting to come back and play the next level.  It has only ever crashed once when exiting the game and was returning to desktop anyway.  Also, when you adjust the volume in settings, the music volume stayed lower than usual until I restarted the game and was fine there after.  After 11.3 hours, I completed every level, only 1 crash total, and I really enjoyed it.

reviewText:
This game is fun to play, however it seems to be lacking in both features and the amount of testing already done on the gameplay. One such example of where things didn't seem to work as intended is where I was no where near any dead bodies and hadn't been seen killing anyone but for some reason got arrested.

I feel that the body guards that are scattered around are irritating as hell as well and feel there needs to be a better way of getting rid of them. Certain levels lack interactivity in terms of traps and seem to rely on you somehow managing to off people one by one in other rooms or out of sight.

I feel that a suspicion meter would make more sense in terms of whether or not theyaccuse you of being the killer (with someone seeing you stab someone filling it up, but someone seeing you next to a dead body as maybe a quarter of the bar, just as an example). This would also go down over time without suspicious acts so as to not penalise players for messing up early on but then doing really well towards the end.

Also, so far the two characters i've played have been exactly the same in every way except cosmetically. I feel it would be appropriate to add more characters and give them special abilities or traits, such as the main hero being able to change masks or something to reduce suspicion, maybe another character who's faster or has more stamina than the other characters and etc. etc.

Overall, enjoying it but finding it rather frustrating when i'm getting arrested for stupid things such as being seen near an already discovered dead body.

Will give 3/5, hoping that certain features get more polish and it becomes a lot less frustrating to play.

reviewText:
Things I learned from Party Hard:

If there's a giant saw soaked in blood, you shouldn't stand next to it.

In shark-infested waters, railings are your friend.

Telling a second, independent serial killer about the party doesn't work out.

You can really cram quite a lot of people into a coffin if you push hard enough.

reviewText:
Enjoy A Real Killer Party !!!

Party Hard

What to expect from this game?
The player is an uninvited guest at a party with one goal in mind, murder. From level to level, the player must terminate all guests, security and the DJ without being caught. For best results, the player should use stealth tactics to complete all goals and evade the police or security at all times. Through practice, the player will find quick solutions to progress through the levels with ease.

What are the Pros of this game?
Hiding Bodies
Poisoning Food/Drinks
Using Bombs/Grenades
Eliminating Witnesses
Set Traps
Dancing With Victims
What are the Cons of this game?
Poor AI Characters (Police, Guests and Security)
Limited Music Selection
Repetitive Gameplay
Unable To Prevent Construction (Mario??)
Limited Weapons
Poor Dancing  (Disco??)
Why do you recommend this game?
I would only recommend this game for fans of horror movies (Scream, Halloween, Silent Night, Valentine's Day, etc.) where the killer could hide in plain sight to prey on their unexpected victim(s). Although this game could be compared to an 8-bit" game
date: I have played better games for Nintendo and Sega Master systems from the 80's. There is no reason for the developers not to make this game better with our current technology.\n\nA Game Recommended For "Horror" Movie Fans Only !!!"

reviewText:
I highly recommend it for those who enjoy letting off a little pent up energy, via stabbing someone in the face. I've beaten this game twice now, and still find the twisted story line to be amazing. The graphics I think add to the overall game play and the nostolgia factor. It comes with a variety of unlockable characters, that each come with their own abilities and difficulties. There's also bonus levels that are not tied to the story line, which just adds on to the creativity of the game.

10/10 I would beat it for a third time!

reviewText:
Party Hard is an unexpectedly addictive indie gem that taps into some primal part of our prehistoric lizard brains. A little remeniscent of Hotline Miami and the SNES Metal Gear games, the high contrast colors, thumping beats and constant euphoric injections gel very nicely to fuel you with adrenaline when you pull off successful sneaky combos.

The game is decently meaty with procedurally generated elements, unlockable characters with different playstyles and custom community maps provide some decent replayability. The story is over the top and predictable but this isn't a game which focuses on narrative. The mechanics are solid and provides a refreshing experience. While it shouldn't be a slow game, some patience and planning is required.

Overall an enjoyable game that's easy to put down and pick up when you've an hour to kill. Definitely play this with a controller and headphones with the bass up. A little tidbit that's nice is that the game also takes over your Alien FX lighting system for Alienware rigs to sync with the catchy soundtrack to create your very own mini disco.

reviewText:
In-depth 3 minute ReviewBelow the short informative review video, you'll also find a written review, should you prefer reading to listening.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4yGvdqBw9DE
GameplayParty Hard is essentially trying to be a stealth game. Every stage consists of one pixelated screen featuring a giant boat, biker party, disco setting and the like. Your mission is to murder everyone involved without being caught. Activating traps usually can be done while being in the vicinity of NPCs, however the act of murdering should be done without being seen, as all NPCs will call the police, which will arrest you, without you being able to actually do much about it, unless you are close to a window to jump through without the cop being able to follow you. As soon as you have been detected, the NPC in question runs faster than you are able to move around the screen and thus a restart is more often than not warranted.
Problems?The premise of murdering partying neighbours is undoubtable funny, however the gameplay for me is too slow paced and not offering enough variation. The peak in the level’s difficulty is right when you started, since, as soon as you cleared a certain part of a level, you can freely murder everyone daring to walk into that area. Most confusing for me was that when the police was called due to your murderous actions, they merely stuff the bodies into bags and are on their marry way again. Future discovery of these body bags does not lead to any response. Thus you can easily murder everyone and just walk away without caring about future discovery, as long as you are not nearby while the body is seen. This leads to a quite boring mid to endgame, when about a third to half of the partying pixelated pornstars have been dealt with. With about half the screen cleared or at least a certain area of the map cleared, you just wait and slowly drag the targets one by one into that part and kill them. This is tedious, repetitive and quite frankly boring. But it still took me about seven to eight minutes after having essentially won the level, to achieve victory without facing any challenge whatsoever. I would love to see more interesting kill mechanics or possibilities of mass murder. Also, the movement speed of the player is sooo slow, even with the running shoe item, you feel sluggish. Overall, for my taste it takes too long to clear the level, with the stage getting actually easier and easier as you progress.
What would rescue the game?The big thing would be to implement some kind of a panic mechanic, which would lead to the rest of the people fleeing from the party, ending the level prematurely after a certain amount of discovered bodies for example. In contrast, if the player would manage to secretly hide the bodies and avoid too much discovery, he would be able to kill more party guests and thus earning much more points, which incentivises more stealthy play.
VERDICTAll in all, I currently cannot recommend Party Hard, as I feel it is too slow paced, bares much challenge and does not offer any interesting stealth possibilities. The Twitch integration is nice, however does not enough to spice up the game for the general crowd.

The goal is straightforward and the retro looking pixelation fits. I can't complain about the difficulty because it scratches the keep-banging-one's-head-against-the-wall-futility itch that makes "Hotline Miami" so endearing.\n\nMy biggest complaint is not one of story but of game coding: the pathing mechanics for the computer. reviewText:
Couple of hours in. Here's what I reckon so far (bearing in mind there's not much to it, two hours feels like enough to judge).

1. It's kind of fun, in general. The standard business of picking folks off alone or in groups is enjoyable for a while. Not super enjoyable for very long, but it'll do for a bit.

2. Elements of the map design are random and this isn't really a good thing. Have done maps that felt really sparse in terms of traps, or that had no food to poison and these can be a chore because you're basically just stabbing everybody. Also the problem with this randomness in a game where you're trying to set high scores is that your high score is going to depend on a good map spawn, which renders the scoring system moot.

3. It's a bit too simple and a bit too random. Way back when I used to play a game called Skool Daze on the Spectrum about being a prankster in a school, and it feels about that kind of level of sophistication. And that was about twenty five years ago. Feels like more could have been done in terms of interacting with the crowd or reading their behaviour. Not asking for realism, just more elements to play with.

4. The traps are often a bit rubbish. You can have loads of fun with poison, especially when people start to blame each other for it, but the others vary between being amazing bordering on overpowered and just being a slightly more cumbersome alternative to a stab. Doing things like blowing up a methlab ought to have more to it.

5. Graphics aren't great. And yes I know Pixel Art is a style, it's not about that. The style is fine, it's just not implemented very well. There is no visual indicator for how far people can see, you have to guess a lot of the time which walls, such as they are, can be seen through, or what height things are at, if they are even at a different height. The indicators for when you've got the cops after you and for when somebody has seen something and blamed another person for it, they work well, but there could be more.

All things considered, it's not offensively bad, it's not hellish, it's not like I've come out of playing it going THIS SUCKS, but it's not Hotline Miami, it's not Postal, it's not even Skool Daze. Some people are going to embrace this game and love it and squeeze it and call it George. If you think you might be one of those people, take a punt on it. Might get lucky and love it. For everybody else, probably not worth the time, and probably only worth the money in a sale.

reviewText: I was intrigued by this one, till I played it. Hotline Miami inspired, but without the frantic pacing or enjoyable puzzle solving. Instead, you're given a series of traps you can try to trigger to avoid being detected as a killer. I was able to trigger nearly all the traps without consequence, including messing with a stove and poisoning some punch directly in front of victims. In some cases, I was even able to knife people without recourse (The party DJ specifically was nailed while playing music, and no one cared).\n\nCan't tell if the voice acting was terrible on purpose, or just terrible. It's not good-hokey either way.

reviewText:
Party Hard is an incredibly mediocre game.

It has a funny, neat idea but is somewhat poorly executed. The stealth system in the game ranges from good to completely random.  I played through and still have no idea why the police would be alerted to me. The basic idea is to kill people who are isolated and then give yourself some distance so that when the bodies are found you are not in the area. This is O'Kay but 50% of the time I will be across the map doing absolutely nothing and they will still pin me as the killer. When this happens you're basically dead because your character moves so slow unless you plan ahead and give yourself distance from the police it's impossible to escape. Basically the way it works is the police chase timer starts off low and then goes up either time they are alerted to you. This leads to a frustrating and slightly boring playthrough. The traps are cool and make things a little more interesting.

Do I recommend it? Not really. TL;DR: Good idea, poor execution.

reviewText:
I really, really wanted to like this game. The idea is fun and it practically writes itself. However, the randomized A.I. really needs some work. Here's an example of my last playthrough.

I enter the party with a large group of people.
I dance on the dance floor for a minute or so, just watching how the NPCs act.
I make my way into the kitchen when it's empty. I remain unnoticed.
I rig the stove as a trap.
I leave the kitchen (still empty) and rejoin the dancers. (still unnoticed)
A waiter enters the empty kitchen alone.
He walks past the oven.
BLAM! Turkey's done.
I'm still on the dance floor, dancing with the NPCs.
Suddenly they all dart away from me, startled.
Handcuffs appear over my head.
A cop rushes in a moment later, attacks me.
I lay in a heap on the dance floor, bloodied and unmoving.
BUSTED

Yeah, no. Not even. Nobody saw me enter kitchen. Nobody saw me in there. Nobody saw me leave. Nobody was in there with the waiter when he died. But suddenly cops are smashing my dental work.

3/10

reviewText:
It's a fun little game but there really isn't much to it. Once you've finished the second level you've almost seen everything this game has to offer. There's only a few other ways of killing people aside from stabbing them and most of these methods will only kill a few people at a time. As a result most levels start to feel like a chore after a couple of kills.

Also, when you get spotted a cop arives and chases you around (you have to run, you can't hide) for a bit until he gets tired and leaves again. It would have been much more interesting if you could hide from him, even if he stuck around and you have to keep avoiding him for the rest of the party.

I just wish there was more strategy involved. It's not a bad game, but unless you like repetitive gameplay I'd say pick this one up for sale, if you can get it for 5$ or less.

reviewText:
Straight to the point: This game is not fun unless you enjoy watching stickmen walking around on screen at a glacial pace

The premise of the game is quite interesting, and I feel like the developers did a good job of delivering on the description. The murder methods are creative, and the semi procedural level generation makes each restart of a level enjoyable in its own right

However, the biggest gripe about this game is that your character walks around far too slowly. This sucks all the enjoyment out of this game; I am not asking for a Hotline Miami style 10-kills-a-second, but making the game slightly faster pace would go a long way in making this game more enjoyable

reviewText:
Party Hard - 20 Steps

1. Go into the party.

2. Gets really irritated by the DJ's horrible music.

3. Kills one person by themselves.

4. Cops.

5. Realises that was only one of 47 people...

6. Only openings to kill are people making love in private.

7. Notices a couple doing it in the bedroom.

8. Lights room on fire & burns them alive.

9. Cops.

10. Fire Department.

11. Everyone else is in the middle & there aren't any environment hazards left...

12. #@%*

13. Notices a fight break out in the party.

14. A man murders an innocent woman.

15. When cops arrive, they run over 5 innocent people.

16. They walk right past the murderer and put the body in a bag.

17. They leave it there.

18. A man enters in a suit.

19. I try to kill him in private.

20. He kills me instead.

Next attempt: Read steps 1-20 again.

-Alternate ending-

Cops arrest you...

Repeat all 20 steps & alternate ending until you get really mad.

~Welcome to Party Hard~

reviewText:
This game is worth a doller... Maybe two.

The price tag is far too high for what you're actually getting.  The story is pretty badly written and the voice acting is cheesy, but that doesn't really matter.

For a game like party hard, the important question is: Is It Fun?

No, not really.  The controls feel slow and sluggish, even the limited sprint option still feels like moving through molassas.  Kill, stuff body in back room, wait for someone to wander close enough, rinse, repeat, fin.  A lot of waiting and not a lot of pay off.  A couple trtaps throughout the level but they're not very fun or interesting to use.

Overall it's like, a 4/10.  If you're interested then pick it up if it's on a really good sale, but otherwise avoid this mediocre crap.

reviewText:
After playing through and finishing this game I can say that I had an okay time of it, but the reason I would not recomend it is how angry this game made me at times, because of the bizzare design choices in this game. So lets list them shall we?

-There are certain enemys that will attack you and knock you to the ground with little warning and leave you lying there for a while, and sometimes the police then show up and decide to arrest you while you are lying on the ground, because the game is programed to do that if the player has been knocked down by NPC's, which normaly only happens if the player openly stabs people in a crowd. But they will still knock the player down later into the level if there are bodys around, EVEN IF THEY DID NOT SEE YOU KILL THEM

-Most of the time NPCs have a very small field of view while other times they will have magic eagle eyesight and see you stab somebody from across the map

-You do not have attack priority, meaning you need to stab an attacking npc by predicting where they will move, this would be okay exept as mentioned before they often attack you with no reason very suddenly and you have no way to counter this

-The random level design can be very annoying because often the traps will be placed in areas the crowd never goes to

-Npcs will always know it was you that killed someone, even if it would be impossible to gain that knowledge from what they saw (such as if a body is in a room with 4 people looking away then they know somehow you are the killer)

-Cops will instantly arrest you if you are the first person they see getting out of their transport, even if you are nowhere near the reported body

-the sword is mostly useless because this game does not reward killing NPCs quickly

-There is no bound button to activate the ninjas power you need to wait, which will result in your detection 90% of the time

-in the endgeme there are FBI agent enemies that cannot be killed by stabbing, you need to kill them only with traps, also they will attack you for no reson and be able to chase you infinitely, and they show up even if you do not kill any cops

-paramedics activate traps when they pass by them and cannot be killed

So that covers it, this game could have been much better then it was but I can still recomend the soudtrack

reviewText: It sounds like a decent concept for a steath-based arcade game in theory, but ultimately suffers from being too repititive past the first few levels.  Nothing really changes from level to level other than different level layouts and having a few new trap effects.  Things actually get really tedious once you're used up all the traps and gimmicks on the level, and there's nothing more you can do but wait for people to slowly move off somewhere alone.  I get it was meant to be simple, but having to gradually hack down 30-40 people while waiting for police and medics to come and go every time quickly becomes more annoying than fun, particularlly if you fail towards the very end of a level and have to start all over.\n\nI'd suggest you watch a Youtube video of the gameplay first and decide if it's something you'd be okay doing over and over again.

reviewText: I tend not to like games with RNG because it tends to screw me over as a player. Risk of Rain, MInecraft, Supermeat Boy have all lost my intrest because the RNG screws me over 9 times out of 10. With Party Hard, there is no exception. Maps are insanely hard and take forever to complete and a single mistake can ruin all your hard work and waste your time. I understand that such an element in this game makes i replayable but its tedious to run around and kill 50 people just to be screwed at the home stretch. Some enviromental objects need to be constants like the food pot and objects that clear groups. Overall i rate this game a 5.5/10

reviewText:
I'm enjoying the game, but I highly recommend getting it on sale.

While I really enjoy the concept behind the game, I feel the game isn't mechanically varied or deep enough to really give the player a rich experience.

The game provides different parties(boat, house, etc.) as slaughtering grounders for the player, but they only really differ in maybe one or two random events. For example, aside from maybe a shark washing up on the boat and eating someone, it isn't meaninfully different from the house party. Most of the gameplay can be summed up as: poisoning the punch bowl, dragging bodies in front of some object rigged to explode, and stabbing lone partiers with a knife. There are exceptions of course, but the aforementioned methods of killing people will constitute your main arsenol.

This game could have been really great if there was just more variety. Adding maybe more weapons or mechanics for the player to use would make this game significantly more interest. Sadly, every level begins to blur into one.

reviewText: This game is decent.  The gameplay mechanics and central idea are fun and interesting, but unfortunately it gets old after a while since there is a very limited number of traps to utilize.  But scoping out a party, planning your moves, and taking everyone out is a satisfying experience nonetheless.\n\nWhat nearly drove me to the point of giving it a thumbs down was the godawful voice acting and the awkward script.  This was the only game I played in recent memory that I had to turn off the sound during every cutscene - it was painful to listen to the dialog.  If they axed that and had text-only exposition, I would have no problem recommending this game (though only if it is on sale for less than $10).

reviewText:
I was super excited when I saw this game. Murder your neighbors because they won't stop partying? Count me in!

Only, the game is practically unplayable.

It's SUPER hard in a terrible way. There's not enough traps on a given level to take everyone out, so you're going to have to stab a fair number of them. This involves waiting for them to wander away from the other people until there is DEFINITELY no line of sight, because that's a very hard thing to tell, stab them, and either hide the body or get out of the room before someone else wanders in, which is very likely because there's a reason your victim wandered over there in the first place. Inevitably there's always two or three that just won't separate, and so you have to try and stab them all before the cops come. Except, while everyone else can run forever, you are apparently horribly obese and can only run for two seconds. So no, you won't catch up with them before they get to the phone, and of course the cops show up immediately no delay.

And there is no difficulty setting. And you can't save during a level, so no save scumming. My latest death (I'm at number 15 or so, and have only made it past level 2) involved me thinking something was a timed trap because literally every other trap so far had been so, only it wasn't and so I electrocuted a musician in front of everybody. Which means that I have to start the whole level over again. Nevermind. I get a better win rate out of solitaire.

If you like pointless exercises in dying, and hate fun, you'd probably like this game. Otherwise, stay away.

reviewText:
Relatively short but fun game with you as a man 'who just wants some quiet'. Your mission is simply to kill everyone at a party, or rather at party after party. Just that - without being spotted and caught by the cops or the bouncers. You can stab people, poison them or use the environment and traps to maim them. All in beautifull 8bit style graphics, and with a pumping soundtrack with 80's beats.

It's a short game (2-5 hours depending on how fast you clear the dozen or so parties), but replayability is guaranteed as you unlock additional characters with different abilities after each playthrough. With those you have to find new strategies to solve each map (eg. the first alternative character may carry bodies without raising suspicion but can't use traps).

It's  well worth it's money even when not discounted. If you can get it at a discount then just buy it. No excuses!

I was swearing and beating my fists every few levels, but the music and humourous characters kept
me in line. It's a lot more accomplishing after you've failed a level a few times and then FINALLY beat it
instead of winning your first try... If you catch what I'm saying.

Voice acting was a little off-putting though, seemed inappropriate for a game where you murder everyone.
A silent cutscene would of done it more justice.. but I still recommend it.

Not too hard, not too easy, not too shabby.

Level Editor would be AMAZING!

reviewText:
Relatively short but fun game with you as a man 'who just wants some quiet'. Your mission is simply to kill everyone at a party, or rather at party after party. Just that - without being spotted and caught by the cops or the bouncers. You can stab people, poison them or use the environment and traps to maim them. All in beautifull 8bit style graphics, and with a pumping soundtrack with 80's beats.

It's a short game (2-5 hours depending on how fast you clear the dozen or so parties), but replayability is guaranteed as you unlock additional characters with different abilities after each playthrough. With those you have to find new strategies to solve each map (eg. the first alternative character may carry bodies without raising suspicion but can't use traps).

It's  well worth it's money even when not discounted. If you can get it at a discount then just buy it. No excuses!

reviewText: This game is incredibly fun. The gameplay is addictive and there is a dark sense of humor throughout the game that constantly rewards the player with hilarious sights and sounds. Cameos from Hulk Hogan, Mario and other pop culture icons make carrying out your task of mass murder a real joy. Good replay value, as there are several unlockable characters that have different abilities and drawbacks. The game is quite difficult, but once you learn the partiers' patterns and the special enemies' weaknesses you should be able to stab your way through to the end. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Interesting game! I've played the game about 4 hours at the moment of writing this review.  I got interested after seeing a live stream on twitch tv.  The idea; a guy can't sleep and decides to murder everyone on the party that kept him awake, got me hooked.

The game shows the area which is semi dynamic from the top. The idea is to lure the guests one at the time and kill them, by either stabbing them or putting a trap. If you get caught killing the police will be called and you have to manage to escape either through hidden doors or by setting a trap in which the police is caught. The only negative thing about the gameplay is that the game sometimes seem to react unfair. You get caught by the police while nobody saw you for instance.

The music in the levels is great and doesn't get boring (or at least it didn't in the few hours i played the game). Graphicaly the game isn't a marvel, but it suits the atmosphere of the game (indy). The silly story also made me laugh, but also made me want to continue playing. it really kept me interested.

I would recommend people to give this indy game a try.

Score 70/100

reviewText:
A fun game with a good concept and a great soundtrack and art style, let down some by repetitive missions and occasional bugs. Earning achievements is easy enough and worth the effort for the added challenge, but the associated character unlocks aren't all that great (the cop is alright). Traps can be fun to use but are all pretty similar, and while the maps do randomise some features, the bulk remain the same throughout.

The game isn't perfect, but it's fun, replayable, and well worth the price.

reviewText:
After spending a decent 11 hours with this game, i have decided to write a review, firstly  this might not be for every one,  due to the nature of the game, if you dont like random acts of murder  it definantly isnt for you , for me however  the fun is in the  acts of murder and trying to rack up as high a score as possible with the inclusion of events on the stages in this game it can either be made easier or harder...i have several times  had moments where a swat team knocked me out, as an example, the music is also bloody brilliant if i have to say so my self, and i highly reccomend  listening to it as its a highly varied and vivid soundtrack, another great thing  is that well, the story is really neat and it keeps you guessing, i certainly didnt see coming what many might have done sure some things could of been done better, but what game doesnt have flaws, i dont see any games without flaws

Pros
Challenging
replayability
Variety
Music
Awesome story Line (in my opinion)
Multiple charecters

Cons
Frustrating at times
Getting spotted when they are all looking the opposite direction
tedious at points

reviewText:
Oh man, the title says it all, PARTY HARD!!!!


Disturbed from your oh so needed slumber.  Your annoying, loud, inconsiderate neighbors are having a party, and you must do something to silence them. All 39-407 of them depending on the scenario. On my first mission, I shoved unsuspecting blondes on the grill with the bratwurst, repeled cowboys with my bad dancing to make them feel awkard enough to walk to the hallway, where I killed them and swiftly shoved them in an ice chest to avoid the cops. The couple making out drunk in the backyard? A tree fell on them, they never found the culprit, (whom is me to no surprise.) Whenever the cops show up,  I hold the Q button and dance until they go away. No one will arrest the dancing guy. Yeah....

I recommend this game, every game should let you dacnce when you hold down Q.

A retro looking game where you get to murder 50-ish people on each level? That's some GTA-like ♥♥♥♥♥!

I like it, and I am not even fully done with the game.

reviewText:
I was super excited when I saw this game. Murder your neighbors because they won't stop partying? Count me in!

Only, the game is practically unplayable.

It's SUPER hard in a terrible way. There's not enough traps on a given level to take everyone out, so you're going to have to stab a fair number of them. This involves waiting for them to wander away from the other people until there is DEFINITELY no line of sight, because that's a very hard thing to tell, stab them, and either hide the body or get out of the room before someone else wanders in, which is very likely because there's a reason your victim wandered over there in the first place. Inevitably there's always two or three that just won't separate, and so you have to try and stab them all before the cops come. Except, while everyone else can run forever, you are apparently horribly obese and can only run for two seconds. So no, you won't catch up with them before they get to the phone, and of course the cops show up immediately no delay.

And there is no difficulty setting. And you can't save during a level, so no save scumming. My latest death (I'm at number 15 or so, and have only made it past level 2) involved me thinking something was a timed trap because literally every other trap so far had been so, only it wasn't and so I electrocuted a musician in front of everybody. Which means that I have to start the whole level over again. Nevermind. I get a better win rate out of solitaire.

If you like pointless exercises in dying, and hate fun, you'd probably like this game. Otherwise, stay away.

reviewText: Waking up due to unruly neighbors is certainly inconvenient but Party Hard from Pinokl games believes that said neighbors deserve to die for that transgression. To that end, the player will attempt to kill all the party goers using his or her trusty knife and/or a few rigged death traps within the environment. While each level has its own look and feel, the problems arise after the first half-hour with the game when you realize you've seen all the unique traps the game has to offer and will spend the rest of the time with Party Hard doing the same thing ad nauseum. For more information, check out the  VIDEO REVIEW:\n\nhttps://youtu.be/xaX9DGBGrac

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong, I've had fun. But it's too expensive at the current price, repetitive, and frustratingly difficult.

I like the concept, and I don't regret having bought it on a sale, but I wouldn't pay more than $5 for this one.

If there's a sale on when you read this, BUY THE GAME! It's a great way to kill a couple hours, nice homage to slasher films, and I'm looking forward to seeing a sequel or remake that really uses the concept to full potential.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, it has some amazing ideas and a good pixel style but it fell short for a few reasons.
First is the soundtrack, the levels are long and you will need to repeat them more than a few times, with each level having a single song that loops it can grate on you easily.
Second is the difficulty, I love a challanging game but I never felt that anything I did right was down to skill, instead it felt as though it was only trial, error and luck.
Finally the story was pretty weak, it was interesting at first but the twist was pretty much the most obvious one possible.

Honestly this game had potential but I never felt as though I was really having fun playing it, the twitch feature was a good idea but it made the game stand out as more lets play fodder and I feel the overall single player experiance suffered as a result.

reviewText: Fun theme, mediocre game. Gameplay is basically whack-a-mole. There's little variation in kills and no tools for luring people. There's also strange logic in some places- you can throw sleepers off a building or into a fan and no one bats an eye... but if you stab someone everyone can see you through the walls somehow... I don't get why this game has so many positive reviews.
voteText: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Pick up a sleeping person and throw them down a roof in plain sight of other people? Noone cares.
Push a person into the shark-infested water in plain sight of other people? Noone cares.
Scare a horse whose kick kills three people? Noone cares.
Get a bit too close to a bouncer? Get busted.
Set off a stun bomb in the midst of a crowd? Noone cares.
Push a person into a fan in plain sight of other people? Noone cares.
Dance badly too often? Get beaten up.
Summon zombies who proceed to turn everyone into zombies? Noone cares.
Stab said zombies in plain sight of people? Noone cares.
Police car just killed a bunch of people by driving over them? Noone cares.
Someone sees a dead person? Everyone freaks out and calls the police.

These inconsistencies out of laziness lead to serious problems with the difficulty.
Easy levels are just those that have a great variety of rooms, traps, and dark corners which make it fairly easy to kill larger amounts of people in a short time.
More difficult" levels have much less of those but due to those inconsistencies
recommended: e.g. you just proceed to pick up sleeping persons one after another and throw them from the roof
hoursPlayed: into the sea
voteText: or into a giant saw. But this means the level isn't really harder to solve
helpfulPercent: it's just more tedious and boring to solve
votesHelpful:
you have less creative destructive possibilities and that means less fun.

In general the game design is lazy and could have much more variety if the people reacted and interacted in a more diverse and more realistic manner and if there was some actual randomization. A level editor is missing as well.

While the game can be fun for a while I can not recommend it for the full price."
