reviewText: Party hard is another great title to add to your steam library. Party hard is a game centered around stealthing through different parties killing everyone in them by any means necessary. With that said this is harder than it sounds with a lot of planning and thought needed behind every move because the police can be called on you and each time they are called back they are harder to avoid than the previous time. So you must use any means you can to take each party goer out one at a time whether that be by stabbing them, poison, or even calling in the swat to essentially do the work for you. Almost every time you play you will have a different experience with each party being randomly generated you might have an item in one go but die and fail and then have a seperate item. Or maybe there is a punch bowl and then the next time there isn't. Those are just some examples. The game itself has a very funny and comedic atmosphere lying under the murderous rage of your character who just wants to get some sleep. The game itself is narrated by an investagator who was on the party hard case tracking the main character down as he ruthlessly slaughtered his way through party after party. The game itself is somewhat of a rinse and repeat experience with generally no switch up in gameplay until the last level, in which you play as a different character who honestly just sucks. So overall the game is great fun but maybe wait for a sale if you can as the $12.89 pricetag is a little steep for the amount of content. However if you don't mind the price I would highly suggest nabbing the game up and playing it through it's well worth the time. 8/10 Great fun. If you would like to see some gameplay here is a link. I almost forgot to mention the excellent soundtrack to the whole game. If you enjoy hotline miamis fast paced techno rave style of music you will more than likely fall in love with this games soundtrack like I did it's certainly one to remember.\nhttps://youtu.be/XkdrjPNhe4Q

reviewText: Ok so I like this. It's macabe to say the least but in a humorous way. It reminds me of an old arcade game you would dump quarters into in the 80's. The gameplay is simple and addictive, the way a game should be. Sometimes you just want to pick up a game and play (without a bunch of keybinds to learn and youtube videos to study). The soundtrack sounds like Herbie Hancock murdered Jan Hammer and did a mix of both thier ♥♥♥♥. reviewText:
After completeing all the levels with the main protagonist, here is my review. 8.5/10
The games random elements keep thing interesting, but I find myself cysling through the rng untill I find one that is a little easier. It does help the game stay fresh when you are repeating a level generally several times.

The difficulty starts relatively high and only continues for the most part as the game progresses.
If you find the first level frustratingly difficult and have played less than 2 hours, consider gettign a refund as it only gets harder.

Level design is wonderful with enough variety that even though the game never changes its machanics it doesn't get boring. With the difficulty so high you genuinally feel a sense of achievement when a level is completed.

The artstyle while simple is brilliant as is the sound design. I just wish there was a fast reset button.

Overall it is the first game in a long time I have completed, one that has challenged me but not to the point of giving up.

I give a solid 8.5/10. Now to continue with the unlockable charactures

reviewText:
Something you might see on Newgrounds or a similar place, but with more of the same content.

Voice acting sounded homemade by a friend or something, none of the mechanics are explained, environments are slightly randomized, but to very little effect. You can walk right into the middle of a drug deal, pick up the... poison..? being traded and walk off with no reaction from anyone (even the armed gaurds you just waltzed past). Going back to stealth, though; It's not even a viable option, unless you'd like to wait hours on end for 50+ AI to randomly wander into your particular zone. Alone, that is. Environment hardly reacts at all in terms of gameplay when they happen upon any dead bodies. As long as they dont see you do it, you're fine. They just call the police, bag the bodies, and leave them to rot without even stopping the party. Also, if the police see you, you can't react at all. You just sit there and take it while they knock you out and arrest you.

More or less a novelty item. The gameplay is one of those things were as soon as you start to understand it and realize how shallow it is, you really have no motivation to play.

(If you watch the clip in the update announcement for the level editor, thats just about the same reaction to that sort of chaos as the AI gives in game as long as they dont see you actively stabbing someone)

reviewText:
Right, firstly I have to say something before I go into the review. There are things about this game that I really enjoy, and both my girlfriend and I have had a lot of fun playing it.

However I have to be honest in reviewing it, and in being honest I have to say that I cannot recommend this game.

Why?

It is basically broken as a game.

No, I haven't experienced any game breaking bugs, but instead, the core game mechanic is entirely flawed because it is simply pot luck in the later levels.

By the subway level you are faced with a party of 44-46 people, with 2 bodyguards who will attack you on sight without provocation, and then after any number of kills, 2 secret agents will show up. These guys break the game. They are faster than you, nearly impossible to kill and will also attack without provocation.

However, if by some miracle you beat them, or they don't show up, the game decides that that isn't good enough and will just have a random party guest attack you without warning. No anger bar, nothing. Just simply kick you to the ground and you are dead.

I have no problem with a game being difficult, providing it is fair and can be beaten with skill and practise. But this game is hard because it is poorly finished. Don't add unwinnable levels just to make a game hard, it doesn't make it better, it just makes me not want to ever load it up again.

Its not the worst game on steam by a mile, but honestly not worth your time unless the game is fixed or altered.

reviewText:
It shares a similar vein to Miami Hotline but is different by valuing stealth over speed. It also has partially procedurally generated levels in that the items used for killing can vary each time you restart a level.

So far, all I've sung were praises. However, this game is far from perfect and the developer should fix these things right away.

1. I can clearly see that the variable weapons/traps in earlier levels are well thought out and polished. However, as the levels go on, the levels become clearly more linear in that the items are the same in each restart. This is not necessarily a problem for all players but as Party Hard favors stealth (biding your time) over a quick massacre, a lack of variables equates to less playability for some. (Especially since there are only 4 characters)

2. A slightly bigger problem, but not necessarily game breaking. In appropriate animations at certain points. People sleeping standing up after dropping them from carrying them. Carrying people without using any hands at all. People floating across the map without initiating the walking animation. All aesthetic stuff since I still had a good time up to this point.

3. Here's the game breaking bug: upon finishing the game and starting as the newly unlocked character, I was unable to bury bodies or interact with traps. Which is vital to completing the game. And since I never (SPOILER) used the 3rd character in the first playthrough, I was wanting to unlock him by completing the second playthrough. Unfortunately, being unable to do anything else other than stab and run, will make that impossible. Trust me, I could not have gone through all the levels on the first playthrough by relying only on my knife and my terrible cardio. (The character in game runs as well as a morbidly obese being).

That being said, I do recommend the game because I felt that it was worth $9.92. But for those looking for a game with good replayability, I suggest watching a few gameplay videos and read a few more reviews before making a final decision because I personally do not think the game is worth any more than $9.92.

reviewText: The gameplay in this odd stealth murder simulator is fascinating, and carried me all the way through until the end. The story is incredibly weak and the dialogue is cringe-worthy nearly all the time. Thankfully, this takes up only a tiny bit of the time you spend playing this game. And the game will suck you in, as each murder party is really a sort of puzzle - some of which take a few tries to figure out, while others are quite easy. The difficulty jumps up and down, rather than ramping up each level, but finishing a puzzle is generally rewarding and failure feels mostly fair.\n\nIt's a weird game. The story is awful beyond belief, predictable, and involves murdering hundreds of innocent party-goers. But it does have interesting mechanics and good puzzle design, that makes me want to recommend it. Unfortunately, the story giving the context that you are basically murdering innocent people makes the game less fun and the story, again, is so, so poorly written that I'm going to mention how bad it is again. So, no recommendation from me.

reviewText:
For a little over 12 bucks, this game is great.  Overall the game is challenging, but usually fun.  All the traps and their resulting  aftermath is fun to work with and the NPCs reactions are gold. There are a fair amount of levels and the layout of the levels is randomized everytime you exit to the main menu or get busted, so if you like a particular setup you can restart until you get it.

I would love to see a brief five minute tutorial where all the rules, effects of items, and NPCs to watch out for are explicitly laid out because with a tutorial the game would be less trial and error.  You never know what an item/NPC/trap/whatever is going to do until you try it and more than once I've tried it and been busted then and there.  There are some newspapers lying around that you can read for tips but they don't go into the finer points of the game.  I've played for over 10 hours and I still don't fully understand how the arrest system works.

Overall 8/10 worth playing at least once.

SPOILERS
Its awesome watching all the NPCs interact (or at least try to); I've gotten people beaten up by a biker (who was then promptly arrested, people sneaking out to kiss (and then some), and people mauled by a dancing bear.

I still have no idea what to do about the special agents

Why does Mario show up to block exits?

reviewText:
Kill everyone without getting caught.

Thats The Jist of Party Hard.  Your a nut job going from one party to the next trying to kill everyone unseen.  Harder then it sounds since each stage is packed with crowds of several dozen people that you have to widdle down a little at a time. if someone spots you killing someone or even near a body that hasn't been discovred then the cops will show up and try to arrest you.  your only defense in these situations are one of the levels enviromental traps (provided you haven't used them to thin  the herd) or failing that you have to pray you can run away long enough for the police to give up and leave.  Unlikely since you move at a snails pace and can only sprint for a couple of seconds and the cops always home in on your position.  It makes for a fun game of cat and mouse...if the mouse was also trying to kill other mice and get away with it.

The game is alot of fun but there is some strange logic you have to wrap your head around that the game doesn't do a good job explaining to you.  Like you can throw someone off a building or push them into a bonfire and no one will bat an eye but if you poisend the food and someone happens to be in the same area as you when they finally drop dead then everyone will instantly know it was you.  Also it seems kind of random when bouncers will come after you.  sometimes you can walk past them and they won't do anything other times they'll try to come after you even if they spot you outside a window.  Its strange but you eventually get the hang of how the game thinks. until then things can seem a bit too random.

Also i'm not a huge fan of the script.  The characters talk like there in a bad max payne spin off or somthing.  I think the game would have been better if they had done somthing like hotline miami or just had no story beyond a party is keeping awake. kill everyone" instead it tries to be an edgey crime drama writtne like a Sin City comic.  Thankfully the story is limited to cut scenes that play after you complete a mission so it never interupts the gameplay its self and i will admit i liked the twist ending.

I had a lot of fun with this game.  I was a big fan of games like Tenchu back in the day and this game scratches that itch Nicely.  It only took me about 5 hours to beat the story but theres some unlockable content and the randomization of the crowd
recommended: and events mean that the game has a decent amount of replayablity.\n\nIf you like easy to pick up stealth games or just want to feel like a masked killer stalking a bunch of college kids then this isn't a bad choice
hoursPlayed: especially for the price."

reviewText:
First of all I state that I bought this game because I liked it when Gronkh played this on Twitch.

This game is about a person who doesn't get sleep and so goes to different parties to kill dozens of people. You can kill them with your knife and with traps. Since there are always different traps and different people each time you start a level, the levels are never the same. So if you play the one and the same level the difficulty varies depending on the items you get, the number of bouncers in the level (who will bust you if you are not careful) and the number and sort of traps you get.

Stabbing people is pretty straight forward, of course you have to be sure that no one sees you or your knife is faster than their legs.
There are many sorts of traps, like poisoning the food, making a horse kick people to death, burning ppl in a stove, etc. If you kill ppl with a trap it will be considered as accident and not murderer even if you push them off a roof (Oh my, that wasn't on purpose). Only exception is poisoning if a poisoned person dies near you, you will be considered the murderer, though this can happen to other NPCs as well. Ppl standing near dead ppl are always considered murderer, even if they didn't do anything (like in real life).
In the levels you can different item. Their use vary. You can have spare clothes so you can change your appearance if you were seen red handed, so the police won't recognize you. With a smoke grenade you can kill people within the smoke without being seen. There is a katana to chop humans in little pieces.
And there are events. like a sharknado when sharks are raining on the party and start to eat the party people. Sometimes there are dancing bears going wild and looking for tasty young teens. You can make phone calls and different things happen, like fast food delivery so the party guests come out of the VIP section, Bikers appear and beat the crap out of everyone, etc.
The time a level takes depends on the way you are playing. If you don't want to be seen and hide every corpse you produce, it can take quite some time to beat a level, like 30 minutes, depending if the party guest are going in a lone corner or stay on the dance floor. If you use traps and kill 2-3 people in a row it takes about half the time. Normal gameplay is somewhere in between.
Oh, and in the game while carrying dead people is a no go, carrying drunk people is considered pretty normal (maybe the developer thinks for some people this is the only way to to literally pick someone up), so you can drag them to a dark and lonely place to introduce your knife to them. ^__^

If you are looking for a nice little game in which you can kill people in various and sometimes funny ways and like to play for short times, I can really recommend this game!

reviewText:
Finally a game where you can murder your noisy neighbours. Just don't get caught. Party goers you may want to look away, but for everyone else have you ever had that moment where you want to slit all those crazy party guests and mingle and do a little stab, stab. Well now you can conscience free. For the psychopath in all of us.

I felt I should write even a short review. I must say the story through each level or round is very heartwarming. It's narrated by the cop and a mystery man, talking the cut-scenes about the life of the serial killer who couldn't sleep and had to kill.
Sometimes you'll get caught with your pants down, it's just a matter of how quick you can outrun the popo.
Challenging but not unbeatable. Background mix was good but I felt there could of been more variation.
Satisfying with a lot of dark humour and a good amount of typical ways to torture and dismember your victims.

reviewText:
Short:
Wait for it to drop to two bucks. It's pretty, but shallow.

Long:
Game's got a fun aesthetic, doesn't rush you, gives you a lot to take in, the music isn't awful, and is paced with the idea that you'd plot out the largest and most interesting kills each semi-random level can offer. But off paper it quickly becomes repetitive and slow, and you start just cherry-picking stray guests that happen to wander near body-hiding spots. Mass kills don't feel hugely rewarding once you've played a level once or twice already, and while there are plenty of Easter eggs, they don't detract from the shallow mechanics. Each level is ultimately the same.

But that isn't even why I can't recommend the game: it has got to have the worst scripting and voice acting of any game I've ever played. I don't  know who their writer/voice actors were, but it's wincing. I've never been embarrassed to be watching a cut-scene before, but this game managed it.

reviewText:
For a little over 12 bucks, this game is great.  Overall the game is challenging, but usually fun.  All the traps and their resulting  aftermath is fun to work with and the NPCs reactions are gold. There are a fair amount of levels and the layout of the levels is randomized everytime you exit to the main menu or get busted, so if you like a particular setup you can restart until you get it.

I would love to see a brief five minute tutorial where all the rules, effects of items, and NPCs to watch out for are explicitly laid out because with a tutorial the game would be less trial and error.  You never know what an item/NPC/trap/whatever is going to do until you try it and more than once I've tried it and been busted then and there.  There are some newspapers lying around that you can read for tips but they don't go into the finer points of the game.  I've played for over 10 hours and I still don't fully understand how the arrest system works.

Overall 8/10 worth playing at least once.

SPOILERS
Its awesome watching all the NPCs interact (or at least try to); I've gotten people beaten up by a biker (who was then promptly arrested, people sneaking out to kiss (and then some), and people mauled by a dancing bear.

I still have no idea what to do about the special agents

Why does Mario show up to block exits?

reviewText: Party Hard is just a great game. It is simple yet sometimes tricky at the same time. The game as a whole is pretty easy but very additive. It is a good game to replay since not every level is the same. The map sometimes changes if you get caught or just want to retry it. so you might not be able to use the same tricks that you used that time on that level. Not only that but you can also unlock characters. New characters mean you can do certain things to make the game harder or easier for you. So you get to go on different murder rampages! The AI can get a little weird though. Sometimes the bouncers would bother you and other times they won't even if you are seen. Then the changing outfits infront of the cops. For some reason the cops suddenly forget you are the killer even if you change righ in front of them. I can't really complain about that though. It has saved my skin a few times. I just wished the game was longer. I went through it fast even though I knew it was not going to be all that long. However, i can not say I was disappointed. The story was pretty interesting even though I did not care about it at first. Either way, the game is great. Different versions of levels, unlockable characters, creative ways to kill 50+ people. It is worth the money. More people should give this game a try because not many games allow you to party hard. It's just a fun dark humor game.

reviewText:
Tl;dr Flawed, recommended if discounted.

Like Hotline, except not really (spree-killing and parts of the aesthetic aside).

For one, Party Hard is very slow-paced. Your character walks at a speed slightly faster than civilian NPC's, can run, but runs out of breath half-way through a reasonably-sized room, and the levels are big enough to notice the slowness of it all. One could argue that it encourages a methodical approach, but in reality, once you find a quiet corner, all you do is press E when someone comes.
The other difference is that violence is not as visceral: most bodies stay intact, regardless of the cause of death, and they don't bleed that much.

Every level contains environmental traps, which allow you to kill about 50-60% of the population, and then it's back to stabbing walkers in a corner. The traps are nice to use, it's a pity there's so little of them on the map. Also, they are randomly generated within the level at every other retry (so, for example, a bike and a horse will swap places, or a music column won't load, etc.), so there is no streamlining a run to perfection over and over, you have to come up with the plan on the go. Considering the aforementioned slow pace and the scarcity of traps overall, this is a drawback for the game.

There is a story. It's presented between the missions and it has some Eh" levels of voice acting
date: but there's nothing mind-blowing or worth mentioning about it. It's just there.\n\nThe tutorialising was done poorly (2 tips you've already understood which are given every now and then)
recommended: the difficulty curve is all over the place
hoursPlayed: some menus are questionable
voteText: and the music is REALLY LOUD even at the lowest setting.\n\nAll in all

reviewText: The game's story is nothing new, and the voice acting could be better, but the game itself is actually a lot of fun to play. There are some very challenging levels, and sometimes I found myself having to restart a level so many times that I ended up hating the level's song temporarily, but none of the levels are impossible to beat. The bonus characters you unlock make the game even more interesting, though I do have to say that I dislike the character you unlock halfway through the game just because their abilities were a hassle to deal with.\n\nOverall, I think that this game is worth buying, and I haven't played anything similar to it recently so it may well be the only game of its kind in your library. The game is surprisingly gorgeous despite being made up of pixel art, and I did like the music used in a lot of the levels. I also appreciated that the levels were randomised-- that is, the layout of a level would be the same no matter how many times you died or restarted, but the positions of the victims, bouncers, and traps would be different every time. I also really liked the fact that there were bonus" levels included after the main story line
date: but they're really weird and I'm not sure why the setting of these levels is the way it is... but it doesn't take away from the game so I can go with it."

reviewText: Such a great concept ruined by such poor gameplay.  Everything about this game looks and sounds awesome, and everything about it *should* be awesome... except there's something really broken about it.  The stealth aspect of the game is completely broken.  The guests are VERY observant and you woll probably end up getting screwed over unless you just stand off in a quiet spot and pick off the guests as they come near you.  There's no way to turn this into a stab-fest and win, but there's also no way to be stealthy within any range of the crowd.  The game still has a ton of potential and there is a chance that it could all be fixed eventually.

reviewText:
If I was to easily describe this game, it would be fun and addicting, this is the kind of game that when you start playing you won't stop until the end.

As you play each and every level you start to feel more and more hungry for the next one, you wonder how the story will follow out, and what's the next move of the Party Killer?

To put it simply it's defintly a game that anyone looking at this review, I hope it encourages you to get it, because trust me, it's worth it

Lastly, but least I'd give it a 9/10 partly because although the level design, and gameplay is brilliant, I still feel that the audio within the story could be worked on a little, and I feel that sometimes there can be too many AI in one place, but apart from that it's a great game

reviewText: I first saw this in an Achievement Hunter Let's Play and it was enough to make me put this game on my wishlist. When the game was included as part of a sale, I snagged it and I have not regretted my decision. Party Hard is a great time killer (no murder puns intended). You play the role of a guy who's so sleep deprived that he's finally snapped and decides that the best solution for putting an end to his noisy neighbor's 3:00 AM party is simply to murder everyone! You've got the basic knife for quick stabbing, you've got a wide array of traps and items you can use to deal with the partygoers, places to dispose of bodies to avoid anyone becoming alarmed...etc. The interesting thing is, that no two playthorughs of any level are the same. There are small changes that occur regularly everytime you play a level such as bear traps, randomly appearing zombie hordes, a shady guy who offers you various illicet goods such as bombs, poison, a sword, etcetera. So get down and party hard!\n\nThe only thing I would change for this game is the option of a profanity filter but that's negligable.

reviewText: Despite the story of this game being horrifyingly terrorist like, it is extremely fun. I found myself playing it far longer than I planed. With unlockable characters and over 10 levels to play, there's plenty to do. The NPC's say funny things, the animations are great, and the music is very catchy (even though it will get repetitive when trying to clear a level for 20 minutes). The graphics are a breath of fresh air in the over used 8-bit style. My only (and very small) gripe is the voice acting of the story cutscenes. It's pure trash. Which is a shame, because the animations and pictures durring cutscenses are great! I would have much rathered them leave the spoken words as text only - it's already subtitled. Thankfully they only last about a minute or two.\n\nI highly recomend this game, if for at least, a time killer.

reviewText:
A simple, chaotic and ultraviolent game, ultimately entertaining if not especially deep.  You play a serial killer who runs through parties across the country with the goal of offing everyone present, anywhere from 30-70 people or potentially even more during certain levels with special conditions, in pre-generated levels utilizing soft randomization of certain elements such as trap layout, item availability and head count.

Killing is easy, as simple as walking up to somebody and pressing the stab key, or setting one of the many traps available throughout the levels.  Getting away with it is the tricky part.  If someone sees a body, they're quick to call the cops and, unfortunately, our hero hasn't done nearly as much cardio as the party-goers and there's little chance chasing down anyone running away from you...or chasing you.  Not to worry though, cops do little to disrupt these parties and will do little more than bag bodies...unless you're seen with a corpse, in which case they'll chase you for longer and longer periods as they become called on more and more.  You can fight them off, of course, though it proves difficult.  Cops, and most special temporary NPCs like paramedics and the Mario-like construction worker, are immune to stabbings (and the non-threatening NPCS to traps as well) so your only hope is to either outrun them (typically with help of special escape routes which teleport you to a different part of the map they cannot follow through and, if you should use one while being chased will call in the aforementioned worker to barricade them) or to lure them into a trap.  Both can prove difficult without pre-planning as cops can easily outrun you and the vast majority of traps are very limited in use.  Manage to off two of them and the Feds show up to scour the map for you, and chances are you won't be coming away so easily from them.

Thus the game, whilst bearing a resemblence in graphical fidelity, era of style, acid-like trips, music and ultraviolence to the Hotline: Miami games, tends to require a more patient, methodical approach than the high-speed twitch action of those titles.  However, like the second Hotline: Miami, you may unlock characters with wildly different abilities for added replay value, such as a stealth character who throws smoke grenades, hides against walls and has a sword strike which can kill multiple victims at once, though alerts anybody who sees him to call the cops, or a woman who kicks people unconcious before stabbing them, allowing you to safely drag victims away from prying eyes, albeit at the cost of precious time.

Also like Hotline: Miami, there's a story to tie all the violence together, but rather than the mysterious, almost noir approach of the former, Party Hard leaves little to the imagination.  Between levels we're offered cutscenes of a police officer who followed the case being interviewed.  The recording is nearly as mediocre as the dialogue, unfortunately, and the plot twists are as cliche as they are shallow, with the writer often attempting to hide their obviousness with nonsensical wordplay.  It's the worst sort of cheese, the kind that takes itself a bit too seriously, though fortunately cutscenes can be skipped to throw you right into the next level.

Ultimately, Party Hard is a fun game which doesn't overstay its welcome.  Very simple with enough level layouts, traps and random events to keep you on your toes, though any longer and it might have been a slog.  It's a good game to turn your mind off to and just have a little fun, but don't expect anything more than that.

reviewText:
I've had a blast playing this game. In short: the pixel style is very nicely done, fits the game well and is very detailed. The story is interesting, you want to sleep to you kill every single person at a party with your stabbing knive.

pros
- Nice style, very detailed
- Music is fun and catchy
- Game is not overly easy
- The levels are not always the same

cons
- Music can get repetative if you take long to finish a level
- Sometimes things ingame happen that do not make sense at all

To elaborate on things not making sense: the level is not always the same. If you get caught or die it spawns other objects, other traps. Which is fine, it adds to the difficulty and does not allow you to make a strategy by just playing a level a lot. However other things do not always have the same outcome, for instance party guests can get paranoid, and when they are overly paranoid they will kick your ♥♥♥ if you are not careful, however sometimes this killed me but other times it just stunned me. Also, escaping from the police, sometimes i have to run 2 paces and he gives up other times i have to run 16 circles. While I like the fact that the level changes in what things it spawns, these type of events should be a little bit more predictable.

The game is challenging some levels took me about 4-5 tries but overall i finished the main game in about 4 hours. There are some bonus levels though you can play after that. However i do not think i want to replay any levels because it takes usually a while to finish it and that is satisfying, doing it another time will not have the same effect probably.

I do recommend the game. Even though it took just 4 hours (excluding the bonus levels which will also take a bit probably) i had a lot of fun with it. Hopefully they will add more content at some point or DLC.

reviewText: 7.6 hours of play time. The game is less a test of skill and more a test of patience. Enjoyable and addicting none-the-less. The complexity of each scenario is pretty well paced as I never felt overwelmed on any particular level however I did feel quite stressed through each stage. Only one wall-/collision-glitch on the Halloween Party level, but nothing game-breaking due to where it is on the map. The story and voice actors are terrible, but if you're overly into that kind of montra while playing a pixelated serial killer then you may have more... personal" issues that should probably take priority.\n\nAll-in-all I have never played anything quite to this exact flavor and enjoyed the new experience. If you're tired of playing rusted-out "tried-and-true" genres then I highly recommend you pick this game up. As for how much

reviewText:
Tedious. Boring. Repetitive.

More ways to say this game is dull. Just write them all down. Never thought a murder simulator, literally that's what it is, could be this big an inducer of somnolence.

All you do is trip whatever traps are on the map and finish off the remaining 90% of your targets one by one. Slowly. Agonizingly. Oh crap you accidentally walked out of a room with bodies in it and the game decided that this time it will have people call the cops because there is a slight angle at which they can see the bodies. Oh noes! Let's run from the coppers!! Oops I stumbled on a piece of the scenery. Guess I'm doing aaaaaaalllll of this again! Such FUNUNUNUNUN!

Seriously the single most I paid money for this so I am going to beat it experience I ever had. I had more fun playing broken Capcom games. I had more fun cleaning up viscera. I actually drove a simulated truck with more passion and care than I gave to murdering pixels in this game.

Do not buy unless you are a twitch streamer, this game is made for you.

reviewText:
Great game that's super addicting. Nice soundtrack. Nice art! Creative death traps! Couldn't stop playing until I beat the game.

However:

--glitches made me want to stop playing (ex: one undead and invisible guest left, frozen and unkillable guests)
--after using the traps the stakes of the game stagnate as you tediously stab guests one by one
--not motivated to play levels over again as unlocked characters. Would be if those characters were in new party levels.
--the cutscenes and voiceovers are TERRIBLE imo. Please let me skip them *prayer emoji

Overall, love it. Would have much better replay value with improvements.

reviewText:
This the first indie title I have played and I was very impressed. The thing about this game is it revolves around understanding the mechanics and patience. I am a big fan of stealth games so I loved Party Hard. It has cool mechanics, a nice story that you learn about between levels and it presents a real challenge. The game is nice because random events take place, but the more you play you understand how they are mostly not random. Someone saw you stab that guy? if something happens to them before they get the phone then you are fine, with more events like this. A note to the developer: While I know this is an indie game I did notice a few things that dont make sense, for example when you are discovered and they tell the cop as he is leaving he just gets in the car and you are fine, and on some levels you get discovered immediately with the ninja. I noticed that this is because events happen in the game as the loading screen is still there. I could move, get discovered and die in that time frame as the ninja depending on the level spawn.
Other than that I give a 9/10 because  the game doesnt tell you all the controls

It took me roughly 10 hours for me to beat the main storyline.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Party Hard is the kind of game that you play when you're bored, but end up playing it for hours. It's an enjoyable experience on its own, but hook it up to your Twitch stream and things become a little more interesting.

Although it has pretty much the same mechanics throughout, the different scenes and varying ways to kill people make the game. If you're a casual player, a YouTuber, or a Twitch streamer, give this game a go.

This game was received for free by the developers in exchange for Lets Play" content on YouTube

reviewText:
We've all been there, trying to get to sleep only to listen to the anti social neighbours blasting out their loud music. Instead of calling noise control our 'hero' takes matters into his own hands and brutally murders everyone associated with the party.

After a very brief opening level to explain the concept its straight into a set of large parties where the objective of the game is to murder everyone. Premise is simple, you can kill people by stabbing them. You must avoid being seen by other party goers or they will call the police who will arrest you and game over. If your seen near a dead body your guilt will be automatically assumed and the police called (even if it wasnt you). In each level you will find a limited number of traps and items like bombs that will take out a group of people at once usually without consequence.

Sounds simple, but it aint. This games takes a lot of patience and thought into successfully completing each level. Unless you get a head start in a chase the cops will always catch you. If you use a trap door or short cut to escape the police a handy man will come along and close it. Other threats could come along like the FBI but also some events that could help you. Prepare to restart over and over. And everytime you restart a level it will be slightly different to what it was in your previous playthrough to keep you on your toes.

Despite it being highly frustrating I recommend this game. Everytime I failed I said to myself one more go, will nail this on the next run. Game is relatively short level wise but potential for new content and I would highly recommend in a sale.

reviewText:
This is a very good game.
The music is great, and that isn't something I usually compliment. The graphics are...well, they aren't meant to be stellar, but it's easy to tell what everything is, and it works.
I've seen people talking about the gameplay being repetitive, and I don't know about that. I guess it can be repetitive. This can be a pretty difficult game until you really get the hang of it. You'll most likely end up trying the same level 3+ times, but the game adjusts for this by randomizing a lot of the items and traps that are available to use. This helps make things a bit fresher, and allows for different approaches to the same level. Now, back to my original thought...is the game repetitive? Yes, but I felt like the gameplay was solid enough that I never felt myself getting annoyed by this.
This is kind of short, but well worth the money. I spent about 9 hours on a single play through, including the times I had to retry the same levels.
The story is interesting, but not exactly something that will keep you on the edge of your seat.
The tutorial should be reworked. It doesn't adequately introduce you to all the tools you have at your disposal. I didn't even know about the listen" action until the final level
date: though I did fine without it. It's never explained what the point of dancing is
recommended: I had to experiment to figure out that it can be used to break up crowds of people that aren't moving.\n\nThe overall experience is very worthwhile
hoursPlayed: and definitely worth the price. Bear in mind that this is a game that relies heavily on strategy

reviewText:
Played first 3 levels, this game has some potentials. You use different ways to kill everyone in the map- kill directly or use the traps. It's not that hard to find traps since they're all marked at the beginning but during the game, the maps looks pretty good and you always have lots ways of killing.

A detective is telling his story to link all those levels- and apparently you are the psycho he's talking about who kills everyone on site without a reason. So kill everyone and survive from the cops is your goal. I found this game not so intriguing due to:

1. You cannot save during one level.
2. Lack of principle- sometimes people see you murder NPC they call the police, sometimes they just ignore you.
3. You can't tell who's watching you who's not. A radar for NPC to display their sight is not rare in many games but this one missed it. You can't tell which direction a NPC is looking exactly or how long one could see. It lowers the fun since you hesitate when you have a good chance.
4. You can't lure NPC to your traps. It's all about luck how many people you kill per trap, and when you run out of traps, killing is painful.

Guys, try Hotline Miami.

reviewText:
This game is basically 'wait for party goer to no be in LoS of the other 50 party goers' -> stab. There are traps which help lowers the numbers a bit... but they are mostly just things walk up to, interact with, then hope in the four seconds it takes to spring people are near so they die. Some traps are no better than just stabbing people.

The mechcanic for getting caught is wonky as well. Cops get called each dead body (and with 50+ people, that's a lot of police) if you don't hide them. But it's a waste of time hiding them though, the police just runs to the body, bags it, the leaves. So if you aren't between him and the found body, you get off scott free.

Controls a wonky and don't always work. Hitboxes seem off as well.

Overall, very dissapointing. I do not understand the rave reviews. Even in the best light, it's bad attempt at a stealth game.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine
Party Hard is published by the wonderful people at tinyBuild Games, and I must say that it is a fun game to play. It mixes stealth with awesome music!

The story is funny yet somewhat stupid, you basically are a guy who tries to sleep but at 3am you wake up to listen to your next door neighbours throwing a wild party, what do you do? You KILL them! The game does have story along the way, after completing a level, it will give you a mini cutscene with some story to fill you in

Basically, the gameplay goes that you are the murderer and you have to try and kill every single party member by any means possible without getting caught by other party guests, the police or any other people. The gameplay is fun and challenging but it can get frustrating and hard  because of the unpredictability of the police and the other guests and that some guests won't do what you want, I wish that the developers would make it slightly easier for us few gamers that don't like very hard games, but, probably they won't...

The music and visuals are really nice to listen to and to look at

Overall the game is fun to play and the developers constantly update the game to feature new levels and new ways to kill your party guests and there is also a twitch.tv integration in which if you broadcast to your twitch channel, the viewers can decide who crashes the party next and so on. The only flaw to Party Hard is its unpredictability and hard difficulty but overall its a fun game to KILL time!

RECOMMENDED :)

reviewText:
A good one. Pixel graphics work well for this one in my opinion. It's fun, has a bit of variety to what you can do. The devs seem to update it from what I've read. Has some random comedy to it.

Pros:
Simple game design
Good levels
Comedy randomness (zombies, aliens, vampires, etc..)

Cons:
Voice acting (at least for me it wasn't easy to listen to)
Score, it feels like score doesn't encourage you to play creatively. If memory serves you get almost double points for stabing someone than you do for setting a trap. You also get more for evading cops than you do for hiding bodies.
Music, it's not bad I can listen to that genre of music, but it only has a few songs for levels and they get old pretty quickly, suggest turning sound off and playing your own.

reviewText: A good idea poorly executed. Party Hard isn't a bad game overall but it has pretty much no playable variety, even when you reach the last stages or unlock new characters it doesn't really feel like you are going anywhere in terms of gameplay, the whole game is what u saw in the first map, straight up. Story video makes no sense for me in this game in particular, it just serves the pretentious purpose of give a context to our actions and tell us the sub story of a detective... i don't really care, i mean, wich are the real implications of that guy in the game? none, don't tell me such things in clips between the levels just show me ingame wtf, that's a terrible decision from my perspective, and by the way, that kind of noir-film ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t conversations displayed in the clips got no logical tie with the colorfull aspect ingame (even being about killing people) it just can not be taken seriously. On the other hand i really enjoyed the classic pixel art of the game, appreciate some of the cool sprites etc. Most of the levels are fun don't get me wrong it just seems like a really early and plain idea with some senseless clips to me. Could be way better. 5,5/10

reviewText:
This game was something I didn't think id be interested in, Being a big fan of hotline miami's fast paced action the thought of stopping to hide bodies didn't seem interesting to me but I picked the game up in the sales for cheap and im glad I decided to play it. It has a multitude of levels to play as well as some bonus levels and the workshop which lets you play other people's levels. With the base levels you get about 6 or so hours worth of playtime though each person might struggle with different levels, miami beach for example, I beat it on my third attempt in about 13 minutes but i've heard some people saying they were stuck on it for an hour and a half.

I had an issue with my PC which made me lose all my data on my hard drive and when I got back up and running I installed Party Hard to find that I had lost my progress ( I was finished the final stage and about to start the bonus stages.) But I kept all my unlocked characters so I got to experience the story a second time in about 2 days it was still fun.

There are unlockable character's, The guy trying to get some sleep, The cop, the ninja, Katie and the butcher, each character plays differently i.e. the cop can carry bodies without suspicion but can't use traps.

Not many games compel me to finish entirely and get all achievement's but this one was definitely good enough to make me do it, Toward the end of the game I already had a good 10 or so achievements out of the 26 I believe and that was with me only trying to get one (the 20 kills combo to unlock the butcher) the others came naturally though the game.

The soundtrack is pretty great though It did start to get a bit repetitive towards the end of missions considering it's a pretty small loop but it's not too bad.

I may start to try get all the cards so I can finish the badge next and i'll basically have done all I can with this game.

I would definitely recommend this game to any one who enjoys Hotline Miami or even Hitman and it's definitely worth the price though if you aren't sure if you'll get what you paid for then wait till the sales and buy it then but I guarantee it'll be worth it!

reviewText:
The game is basically a stealth-murder simulation, where you tatically plan how to kill the party goers. Would you like to push them into hazardous objects such as fire, bbq grill, saws, shark-infested waters, etc..Or would you like to massacare a group of them while making sure none of the escape. Perhaps, you want to ♥♥♥♥ of animal to slaughter the guest, maybe turn on a car to mow down what's left. There are many ways to kill in this game, and while I wish there were more traps per level, I can see how the game could get too easy. Speaking of difficulty, this game will provide a challenge, do not expect to go on a killing spree without failing the next few seconds (unless your the butcher character).

Pros:
Five different characters
Cheesy storyline
Variety of hazardous objects
Variety in level design
The thrill of stabbing an unsuspecting victim.
Calling various types of reinforcements (zombies, firefighters, pest control, swat team, another serial killer)
Many levels

Cons:
Cheesy storyline
Not that many types of weapons.
More hazardous objects per level

Overall, I bought this game for around $7 and I beat it in 7 hours, money is well spent and I'am more than satisfied with my purchase. Understand, that while I may have only played 7 hours, there is more than 7 hours worth of conent as the replaybility is high and their are user-created levels, not to mention unlockable characters.

reviewText: Party hard is basically a slasher movie where you play as the slasher. When I started playing Party Hard I immediately thought of Hotline Miami where you are a slasher who has to strategically set up the moves that you are going to make to reach your end goal which is to kill everybody in a 2 mile radius. The differences between the games are that with Hotline Miami you can get frustrated and just go on a murder spree and you will win but with Party Hard they will call the cops who will then arrest you and cause you to start all over again. Some of the problems I have with Party  Hard is that since it uses a board game like view it is hard to tell where you are in between the 60 other people. Also when somebody calls the police on you it's really hard to kill them before they get to the phone because they will run to phone and you are stuck with a slow walk or a fast walk at the most. That's really all I have against it so if you like games like Hotline Miami then you will really enjoy this game.

reviewText:
I'm so glad they released this for Mac. I remember seeing a let's play of this and thought it looked really fun. Well, it is!

Firstly, the music is incredible. It reminds me a lot of the music in hotline miami 1 & 2. The visuals are pixel-y, but in a good way. The cut scenes and story are interesting and gives nothing away, which really drew me into this game even more.

The gameplay is straight forward and doesn't overload you with a bunch of controls. It's more about knowing what to do and when, seizing an opportunity, that kind of thing. You can play however you like as well. You could be the dude hiding in the bushes waiting for people to stray away from the crowd or you could go wild and start knifing people left and right before throwing on some new clothes to throw the cops off the trail. Tons of traps, body disposal, and random events to give this game a lot of replay value.

There's also something morbidly cathartic about murdering people for the sake of getting some peace and quiet. Also, the sweet music that plays when you beat the level is nice too.

reviewText:
Party Hard  is a topdown classic 'clear all enemies' game with a different and interesting mechanic. First of all if you have played Hotline Miami 1 or 2, then you may go into this game thinking that it is very similar. It is not.  Party Hard  is actually more reminiscent of the original Metal Gear games, while still having SOME feel of Hotline Miami. The main objective of  Party Hard  is to eliminate all enemies in the stage without getting killed or arrested. The trick is, that if a party member sees anything suspicious, like dead corpses and you stabbing people, then they will likely attempt to call the cops. If you are not seen committing the crime, then the cops will NOT come after you. If you have handcuffs over you, then the cops are onto you and you must try to evade them to continue your mission. Upon completion of each level, a little story is told to the player of a police officer who was investigating the 'Party Hard' killer(you). Each level gets harder and harder, as well as includes a multitude of items, traps, and anything else you can think of.

Party Hard  is another instant steam classic and a must have, all though not much content, it is very enjoyable and actually quite a challenge. It also nails the soundtrack department, having possibly some of the best tracks of 2015. The graphics mimic the simple style of old SNES games, which is always a plus for me, at least.

Final Verdict:

Gameplay(75%): 9/10
Story(15%): 8/10
Soundtrack(7.5%) 10/10
Graphics(2.5%) 9/10

PARTY HARD

94/100

reviewText:
This the first indie title I have played and I was very impressed. The thing about this game is it revolves around understanding the mechanics and patience. I am a big fan of stealth games so I loved Party Hard. It has cool mechanics, a nice story that you learn about between levels and it presents a real challenge. The game is nice because random events take place, but the more you play you understand how they are mostly not random. Someone saw you stab that guy? if something happens to them before they get the phone then you are fine, with more events like this. A note to the developer: While I know this is an indie game I did notice a few things that dont make sense, for example when you are discovered and they tell the cop as he is leaving he just gets in the car and you are fine, and on some levels you get discovered immediately with the ninja. I noticed that this is because events happen in the game as the loading screen is still there. I could move, get discovered and die in that time frame as the ninja depending on the level spawn.
Other than that I give a 9/10 because  the game doesnt tell you all the controls

It took me roughly 10 hours for me to beat the main storyline.

Thankfully they only last about a minute or two.\n\nI highly recomend this game, if for at least, a time killer.

reviewText: Fun little game for a few hours.  The theme is you are a psycopathic serial killer that has been woken up by roudy parties so you kill everyone so you can get some sleep lol.\n\nRetro graphics, unique and silly gameplay. Its actually a very basic stealth game with elements of Watch_Dogs, to a small point. That is, you set off traps to kill as much, hide bodies and sneak around while trying to blend in. Some funny elements like setting off cars to run people over, setting off fires to blow up a room full of people while you exit, throwing people over the boat to the sharks and such.  You avoid being seen by the crowds by picking off isolated people (or large groups via traps), discarding bodies in sewers, over the boat and trash dumpsters. The police are a factor and are called when dead bodies are seen and if you were spotted you need to run from them...RIP and get some rest.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Skip to the bottom for TL;DR

On paper and indeed in the desciption- this seems like a cheesey, but entertaining premise for a game.

Your character is a bitter and tired individual looking to take out his rage and frustration on those keeping him awake while simultaneously not getting killed/arrested- an idea that seems very cathartic and was enough to make me want to give the game a spin.

The tutorial is a brief mission comprising of 4 or 5 individuals laid out in a way to THEORETICALLY teach you all you'll need to know throughout the game, but it only teaches you how to stab people and introduces you to the fact that environmental interactivity will be a thing in this game.

The next mission proceeds to inject you into a party of FORTY SEVEN people. Not only does that up the ante significantly, but this is our first introduction to more/different contextual environment kill options that we don't know the ramifications of screwing with.

I.e; if I poison this food do people die on the spot? Do they walk around choking? Will they not know they're poisoned until they suddenly drop dead?

Simultaneously; how will people react to finding dead bodies? The only level I've played thus far is laid out in a way that I can't determine this.

If the police are called on me; how do I get away? Can I resist arrest?

If I use this phone, who do I call? (I got two different results- some weird bulky guy and an exterminator team with no way of distinguishing which would show up)

I've noticed from having to restart various levels that some rooms/areas in certain levels are randomized and the things within them are as well meaning that you can't bank on a certain item being in the same place if you fail at any point (this isn't necessarily bad, but it's a bit unexpected that I wasn't prepared for)

In my mind this is Party Hard's biggest failing: it gives us way too much way too soon and doesn't explain enough before letting us go crazy at bigger parties.

Calling the police, fire department, weird Russian guy, etc will cause them to suddenly rush into a level, run over eight people standing out front, rush into the party to do whatever it is they're there to do, run back to their cars, book it, and run over four more.

While it does make my job easier it creates a solid disconnect from the story of some detective guy recounting the investigation of the Party Hard Killings" (or "Killer"
date:
can't remember off the top of my head) when his coworkers are responsible for near as many deaths in the course of my rampage.

On a final note; human life has little-to-no meaning to anyone in this game. Five dead people on the dancefloor? PANIC! CALL THE COPS! PANIC A LITTLE LONGER! Oh the bodies are in bags now? Back to dancing right on top of them!

There's no reward for being extremely cautious besides not having the cops called directly on you while simultaneously there's no risk for just leaving a body where it falls because if someone does call the police about it the cop that comes to investigate will just bag it before taking off again and leaving it there.

All this combined just ends up with Party Hard not being fun.

It attempts to make us believe there's a level of depth that just ultimately doesn't exist because once we've sabotaged the stove
hoursPlayed: knocked two trees through the windows
voteText: stabbed some guy at his computer
helpfulPercent: shoved a guy into a fire
votesFunny: and shoved four more into freezers
commentsCount: garbage bins
column16:
and manholes- there's still twenty more people to be killed and I'm fresh out of novelty/environmental/contextual kills. So at that point it boils down to stalking the rest of the partygoers one-by-one as they split off from the main group over the next ten minutes before decapitating the DJ and dancing my way to the next level.

Bottom line: Party Hard just isn't fun because it quickly becomes tedious and there's just too much going on too soon. Combined with too many options that don't do enough damage to the partygoer numbers and aren't explained well enough to understand immediately or sometimes even after repeated use.

TL;DR- Party Hard is a less interesting

reviewText: 7.6 hours of play time. The game is less a test of skill and more a test of patience. Enjoyable and addicting none-the-less. The complexity of each scenario is pretty well paced as I never felt overwelmed on any particular level however I did feel quite stressed through each stage. reviewText:
Bought this game on sale for 50% off but it is definitely worth the full price. Simple but has an interesting story, the cut scenes are especially good and I look forward to them as much as the levels. Some of the levels seem a bit harder than necessary as in at least once a map there is really no way to stealth and you will just have to kill the 2-3 other people before they can alert others elsewhere or call the cops (otherwise you better have a extra set of clothes).  Also I noticed repeating a level the same items may or may not be there, which can make things easier or harder.

Music is really enjoyable, if you enjoy edm/club music this is right up your alley. I usually find myself wanting to turn down the music provided in most games but I definitely bump this louder.

I reccommend this game for people who enjoy stealth but are looking for something lighter. I find myself laughing during some of these kills with the characters acting like typical party crowd". If you don't typically enjoy stealth you will probably still find this game entertaining but might find yourself giving up or getting annoyed since there is little room for error in the levels before starting all over again.

I haven't built my own levels yet but the feature is there and very entertaining. Think of it like the killer version of mario maker LOL.

Overall: 8.5/10"

reviewText:
Short:
Wait for it to drop to two bucks. It's pretty, but shallow.

Long:
Game's got a fun aesthetic, doesn't rush you, gives you a lot to take in, the music isn't awful, and is paced with the idea that you'd plot out the largest and most interesting kills each semi-random level can offer. But off paper it quickly becomes repetitive and slow, and you start just cherry-picking stray guests that happen to wander near body-hiding spots. Mass kills don't feel hugely rewarding once you've played a level once or twice already, and while there are plenty of Easter eggs, they don't detract from the shallow mechanics. Each level is ultimately the same.

But that isn't even why I can't recommend the game: it has got to have the worst scripting and voice acting of any game I've ever played. I don't  know who their writer/voice actors were, but it's wincing. I've never been embarrassed to be watching a cut-scene before, but this game managed it.

reviewText: I can't believe that I didn't stumble upon this game sooner. Very interesting concept. You play as a guy who's just trying to get some sleep, but your neighbors are throwing a party. Your goal is to kill everyone at the party without getting arrested or killed. While you'd think that a game with such a premise would be completely tasteless and without merit, I have to say that the simple graphics and the generally comedic tone keep you from taking things too seriously. My only real gripe is that most of the game play mechanics seem to be somewhat unnecessary, although I suppose that mastering them may allow you to proceed through the game more quickly.

reviewText:
While the game looks and sounds very nice, in the end, it just isn't fun. There's enormous potential here, but it isn't utilized the way it could be.

Traps are one-use-per-level, and rarely take out enough people to be considered effective. By the time you've used up all of your available traps, there's still 20-30 people left to kill. This means you have to wait for each of them to move to a secluded spot so you can kill them.

Additionally, being seen next to a dead body means the police will be called on you. In many cases, you have nowhere to run, and even your (extremely limited) sprint isn't fast enough to escape. If a cop grabs you, you instantly lose and have to restart the level from the beginning. For me, this meant spending an hour on one level, waiting for people to wander from the group so I could kill them, only for someone to see me and force me to start from the very beginning.

The game has a ton of potential, but it just isn't executed well at all. If there was a way to lure people towards traps or to more easily escape the police, the game would be much, much better. As it is now, it just turns into a long, tedious grind.

reviewText:
This game is really one of my faves. I'd go as far as to call it a spiritual successor to Hotline Miami- even used the same font as it! The gameplay is fun, easy to learn, and frustrating. A simple miscalculation and you've lost the entire level. The generated levels can work for or out of your favor, but each one can be won with some careful planning. And the soundtrack? is really amazing. Short list of tracks but I've had it on repeat for quite a while. Last but not least, the cutscenes- while the voice acting isn't incredibly mind blowing - are a really good accompaniment to the gameplay. The game would have been great without them, but they went the extra mile and made it something interesting. The game is a solid 9/10, a point gone for that one time a bouncer was hiding behind a door and I had 9 people left. Still miffed about it.

At least, a 9/10 until the end. The very end- 'last cutscene and the game is done ' end. I won't get into the details, but it's a very cliche and overdone trope in horror and murder games and movies. There were many other ways it could have been done and still held the same excitement, but they still took the easy way out. The end seems like a copout (excuse the pun) of an ending and feels very, very out of place with the rest of the story. I don't usually let bad ends get to me, but this one just didin't feel right with the game.
I would still recommend it of course, but I'd also recommend ignoring the last cutscene- skipping it altogether even. It leaves you with a bad taste in your mouth.

reviewText: A good idea poorly executed. Party Hard isn't a bad game overall but it has pretty much no playable variety, even when you reach the last stages or unlock new characters it doesn't really feel like you are going anywhere in terms of gameplay, the whole game is what u saw in the first map, straight up. Story video makes no sense for me in this game in particular, it just serves the pretentious purpose of give a context to our actions and tell us the sub story of a detective... i don't really care, i mean, wich are the real implications of that guy in the game? none, don't tell me such things in clips between the levels just show me ingame wtf, that's a terrible decision from my perspective, and by the way, that kind of noir-film ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t conversations displayed in the clips got no logical tie with the colorfull aspect ingame (even being about killing people) it just can not be taken seriously. On the other hand i really enjoyed the classic pixel art of the game, appreciate some of the cool sprites etc. Most of the levels are fun don't get me wrong it just seems like a really early and plain idea with some senseless clips to me. Could be way better. 5,5/10

reviewText:
Played first 3 levels, this game has some potentials. You use different ways to kill everyone in the map- kill directly or use the traps. It's not that hard to find traps since they're all marked at the beginning but during the game, the maps looks pretty good and you always have lots ways of killing.

A detective is telling his story to link all those levels- and apparently you are the psycho he's talking about who kills everyone on site without a reason. So kill everyone and survive from the cops is your goal. I found this game not so intriguing due to:

1. You cannot save during one level.
2. Lack of principle- sometimes people see you murder NPC they call the police, sometimes they just ignore you.
3. You can't tell who's watching you who's not. A radar for NPC to display their sight is not rare in many games but this one missed it. You can't tell which direction a NPC is looking exactly or how long one could see. It lowers the fun since you hesitate when you have a good chance.
4. You can't lure NPC to your traps. It's all about luck how many people you kill per trap, and when you run out of traps, killing is painful.

Guys, try Hotline Miami.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine
Party Hard is published by the wonderful people at tinyBuild Games, and I must say that it is a fun game to play. It mixes stealth with awesome music!

The story is funny yet somewhat stupid, you basically are a guy who tries to sleep but at 3am you wake up to listen to your next door neighbours throwing a wild party, what do you do? You KILL them! The game does have story along the way, after completing a level, it will give you a mini cutscene with some story to fill you in

Basically, the gameplay goes that you are the murderer and you have to try and kill every single party member by any means possible without getting caught by other party guests, the police or any other people. The gameplay is fun and challenging but it can get frustrating and hard  because of the unpredictability of the police and the other guests and that some guests won't do what you want, I wish that the developers would make it slightly easier for us few gamers that don't like very hard games, but, probably they won't...

The music and visuals are really nice to listen to and to look at

Overall the game is fun to play and the developers constantly update the game to feature new levels and new ways to kill your party guests and there is also a twitch.tv integration in which if you broadcast to your twitch channel, the viewers can decide who crashes the party next and so on. The only flaw to Party Hard is its unpredictability and hard difficulty but overall its a fun game to KILL time!

RECOMMENDED :)

reviewText:
I have to say, Party Hard is one of the best stealth games I've ever played.. OUO You basically play as a person trying to kill everyone at a party. You only start with a knife at your disposal but there are many different traps and items that can be used to make the killing easier.

The gameplay is excellent, but I feel that there were a couple minor issues that some have run into (but I don't mind them much.) I think the game might be considered a bit unfair when you'll be close to finishing a level, only to lose because of something you weren't aware of. However, a game like Spelunky requires you to learn these elements of gameplay yourself so you don't make the same mistake twice, and I can respect it for that. The game's might be a bit hard at first, but that's the charm of Party Hard.

..I don't have much else to say, except if you want a really good stealth game, Party Hard should not only meet your expectations, but skyrocket past them. :)

reviewText: This is a very stealth/strategic game (much like how a slasher killer would act), using mechanics like traps, isolated clean kills, phone calls to whoever/whatever can assist you etc. What I REALLY like about this game though, is the nice replayablility it has. Every stage alters in it's own way, whenevery you restart it, die, replay, whatever. (For example: This trap will be here, this weapon won't appear on the map this time, the phone will signal this guy instead of that guy etc.)\n\nAs far as difficulty is concerned, it was a major challenge until I understood how the game worked, but in all honesty: there are so many unique features to discover, that even losing felt like winning. :D

reviewText: Party hard is basically a slasher movie where you play as the slasher. When I started playing Party Hard I immediately thought of Hotline Miami where you are a slasher who has to strategically set up the moves that you are going to make to reach your end goal which is to kill everybody in a 2 mile radius. The differences between the games are that with Hotline Miami you can get frustrated and just go on a murder spree and you will win but with Party Hard they will call the cops who will then arrest you and cause you to start all over again. Some of the problems I have with Party  Hard is that since it uses a board game like view it is hard to tell where you are in between the 60 other people. Also when somebody calls the police on you it's really hard to kill them before they get to the phone because they will run to phone and you are stuck with a slow walk or a fast walk at the most. That's really all I have against it so if you like games like Hotline Miami then you will really enjoy this game.

reviewText:
I got this game as a review copy from TinyBuilds, but this review is not affected by this in any way.

Party Hard is a game in which you go from party to party killing everyone as a psycho.

The game.

The objective of the game is to murder everyone without dying or getting caught by the cops. You can do this by simply stabbing them or using the party as your killing machine. The levels are sandbox and each time you play the interactable objects in it change, which is a great feature as you experience a different gameplay every time you play.
There are a lot of ways to kill people, you can ran them over with a caddy, make a bomb out of a gum machine or even call Jason to cut everyone in slices. A lot of random events help keep the game different each time. You might find lesbians making out in the bathroom, or a terrorist putting a bomb in the middle of the dancefloor. You can also find usable objects such as swords, bombs and poison.
The game is quite funny sometimes. I found a man ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on a dead body while two guys insulted each others moms. Between levels you get cutscenes of the police officer who investigated you talking to a psychologists, which are actually quite funny.
The graphics are pretty and you can understand what each person is doing(which is impressive for this kind of pixel art)The mechanics are tight and responsive. Also,this game features full Xbox controller compatibility.
I wrote an email to the publishers and they replied in a record time of 1 hour and 30 minutes. The community makes a lot of adicional scenarios which increase the replayability of the game.

Conclusion

The game feels like if a psycho Hitman was playing RobberyBob with pixel art. The 2000`s music fits great with the game. It is well worth the 13 bucks they ask for. Easy 95/100

reviewText: This is one of the most fun and addictive games I've ever played. It's simple enough to drop into casually, but a challenging adrenaline rush once you get started. There's a constant dilemma: to make a risky strike or wait for the perfect moment. As the levels get harder, you can't always win on patience and strategy alone. You have to take risks. Small details on the level randomize just enough to keep it interesting if you end up retrying a level many times before beating it. And, there were enough clever surprises to keep me always determined to make it to the next level.

reviewText: This game, as many others said, is very reminiscent of Hotline Miami in its art style and gameplay, though it is nowhere near as fast-paced as HL:M. It has a very interesting gameplay mechanic, in which you must stealthily kill all the party members without being arrested. Granted, there are ways to kill everyone blatantly, but it makes the game harder. I would recommend it because it has a unique style about it and is a good time waster. The only reason I bought it is because it was on sale. It's not worth more than $5, in my opinion. The storyline is extremely flat, and I found myself muting the music halfway through the level because it's the same 15 second loop over and over again. The voice acting is very sub-par, and almost cringy to a point. It's still a decently entertaining game that offers a modest challenge. 6/10.

reviewText:
This game is alright. The concept is fun, but isn't anything revolutionary. This game has the most unrealistic AI I've ever seen, which can be seen as both a good thing and a bad thing. I'd like to rename this game You'd think at some point..." because that's what you'll be yelling at the game the entire time you're playing.

"You'd think at some point they'd cancel a party after 30 people have died."
"You'd think at some point they'd catch on to a guy awkwardly running around with a Jason mask."
"You'd think at some point the cops would just stick around after being called for the tenth time."

While I believe the game is worth getting
date: the game doesn't require as much stealth as it would have you believe. The people have pretty narrow cones of vision
recommended: and if you outrun the cops you are immune to getting arrested until they leave the scene completely. You can hide the bodies you kill so that the cops aren't called
hoursPlayed: but as long nobody saw you actually kill the person you'll never get in trouble. Just some things to keep in mind if you are looking for a good stealth game instead of a silly diversion. Worth the price
voteText: though."

reviewText: If you need a game to play while you wait for your friend to pick you up for dinner, but don't want to dive head first into Fallout or have time for a full out CSGO comp game, I reccomend getting Party Hard. Sit back and stab following the story of Mr.West as he tells the story and tries to solve the mystery. reviewText:
This game is really one of my faves. I'd go as far as to call it a spiritual successor to Hotline Miami- even used the same font as it! The gameplay is fun, easy to learn, and frustrating. A simple miscalculation and you've lost the entire level. The generated levels can work for or out of your favor, but each one can be won with some careful planning. And the soundtrack? is really amazing. Short list of tracks but I've had it on repeat for quite a while. Last but not least, the cutscenes- while the voice acting isn't incredibly mind blowing - are a really good accompaniment to the gameplay. The game would have been great without them, but they went the extra mile and made it something interesting. The game is a solid 9/10, a point gone for that one time a bouncer was hiding behind a door and I had 9 people left. Still miffed about it.

At least, a 9/10 until the end. The very end- 'last cutscene and the game is done ' end. I won't get into the details, but it's a very cliche and overdone trope in horror and murder games and movies. There were many other ways it could have been done and still held the same excitement, but they still took the easy way out. The end seems like a copout (excuse the pun) of an ending and feels very, very out of place with the rest of the story. I don't usually let bad ends get to me, but this one just didin't feel right with the game.
I would still recommend it of course, but I'd also recommend ignoring the last cutscene- skipping it altogether even. It leaves you with a bad taste in your mouth.

reviewText: Fantastic game. You get to be a killer who is just trying to get some sleep. I enjoyed it because you don't just use a knife to kill the people around you. You use what is in your surroundings and you try your best. One of my favorite things is calling in someone. There are times that you don't know what you would get and that alone adds to the fun. If you don't mind trying to figure out the best way of killing people without alerting the cops or trying to escape the cops. It's a interesting puzzle and it leaves for the game to play more than once.
