reviewText: Although flawed, I LOVED this game.  Something to me was immensely satisfying about timing kills, hiding corpses, and setting up traps for maximum damage.  Since the enemies seem to move a bit randomly, however, it can be frustrating.  In addition, the player isn't given much information about when the cops will give up" the chase.  Sometimes it seems to happen as soon as you depart through a trap door - other times
date: police seem to follow you almost indefinitely.  If you enjoy a novel premise and have the patience
recommended: Party Hard is worth your time."

voteText: true

reviewText: Welcome to Party Hard, where you play as a man with the stamina of someone who's never ran before in his life against a group of party people who have each been trained to run a marathon. Where pushing people into open flames is A-Okay, but standing 5 feet away from a dead body is not. Party Hard is a unique stealth game that has you kill groups of about 50 people without alerting the cops. Although the mechanics may seem tricky at first, a bit of patience and experience makes this game very enjoyable. There are about 10 maps to the story, each lasting about 10~15 minutes (depending on luck and skill). After a few frustrating mistakes, being able to complete a difficult level is extremely satisfying. The game itself is not very long, but with the level editor, you are able to create and play on maps made by other players. Overall, I'd say this game is worth the price if you enjoy stealth games, but could probably be held off on until a sale comes by if the video and screenshots dont really catch your eye.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
My one word review.

Disappointing.

How the game was advertised and pitched: Hotline Miami style pixel murderspree with crazy parties and quirky exciting scenarios. Sheer insanity and fun!

How it actually plays.  A slow, tedious test of patience and frustration. Most of the people you'll end up killing just from slowly walking at them and hitting E when there aren't any witnesses and then dropping their body somewhere, wash, rinse, repeat. If something goes wrong there isn't really any gameplay afterwords, which is where I'd expect a game about chaos to excel in the what happens when unexpected things happen" but alas.

If you get spotted a police office gets a homing beacon to your position and you can escape by hopping back and forth across a barrier the cop can't cross for some reason. Then the cop gives up and calls a repairman who "fixes" the barrier so you don't do that again
hoursPlayed:
little murderer. There is one or maybe two other similar hopping points on the level which function largely as extra lives.

The special events for the most part don't really to be the focus of the game at all and are mostly downplayed relative to just shanking people. Many events only kill a single person and give away your location. Others like poisoning food get similarly poor results without you being spotted but do force you to wait for excessive periods of time to the results.

As a result I entered with high hopes but left with a largely unmemorable experience. I think it'd be possible to make this game good still but it would require a lot of work on the core game loop and mission design so I'm dubious we'll ever see it.

Disclaimer I only played through the first level and tutorial but I watched some let's plays to make sure I wasn't missing really cool stuff later on and it continued to meet my expectations. I also checked with a friend who had beaten most of the missions and he was similarly disappointed. I would stay away. Watch the trailers

reviewText: Strategy? Stand and wait till there are a bunch of people by a trap and trigger it.  Stealth? reviewText: 88/100\n\nParty Hard is a singleplayer, stealth, indie game with pixelated graphics. It is very strategy based and requires patience. The story is fairly simple, you play as a guy who is just tryna' get some sleep, but of course your neighbours are having a party. You can kinda' tell what goes on from there. You can also unlock more characters with special traits as you unlock achivements, so thats a plus. The game has a very good sense of humour as well, which makes much more fun to play. Oh, how could I forget? The Soundtrack! You can not have a good game or party without good music, and boy this game has got it. It's soundtrack is honestly one of my favourite, although it may get a little repetetive sometimes. The only thing I didn't like about the game was the fact that the story is too short, although there are bonus levels after the story, it still isn't as fun as the story. Overall this game is great and I totally recommend it!

Where pushing people into open flames is A-Okay, but standing 5 feet away from a dead body is not. Party Hard is a unique stealth game that has you kill groups of about 50 people without alerting the cops. reviewText:
I barely recommend this game.  It has just enough positives to outweigh the negatives.  Here's the plus side:
-Great soundtrack
-Interesting fresh concept
-Fun somewhat polished gameplay and fairly difficult, exercises patience and cleverness.
-Fair price, decent amount of level choices including an in depth level editor.
-Depth in the certain combinations of interactions between characters, including cheeky cameos.
-Certain interactables cycle after each play of some maps keeping some freshness and flexibility.
Negatives:
-Heavy Euro Jank(Spelling errors, poor grammer, story is messed up, voice acting cringe worthy)
-Game Sounds are limited, repetitve and often inaccurate(everyone sounds like an old man when they die)
-Game does not have much variety in the mission, just kill everyone.  Game gets harder but all an all not different.
-Has mild bugs that still make the game playable but they are there.

For most people, you'll get a few hours of fun out of this game.  I've played some flash games for free that were more polished than this game.  So I suggest waiting for it fall within the 5 dollar range to be considered worth your money.
